title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Check the circuit.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: It can't be the screen then. Definitely something out there,  Captain, headed this way.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Their call letters check with a survey expedition. SS Columbia.  It disappeared in that region approximately eighteen years ago.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Records show the Talos group has never been explored. Solar  system similar to Earth, eleven planets. Number four seems to be Class  M, oxygen atmosphere.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: We aren't going to go, to be certain?

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Preliminary lab survey ready, sir.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Yes, sir.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Spock here.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: There is no survivors' encampment, Number One. This is all some  sort of trap. We've lost the Captain. Do you read?

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: The inhabitants of this planet must live  deep underground, and probably manufacture food and other needs down  there. Our tests indicate the planet surface, without considerably more  vegetation or some animals, simply too barren to support life.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Exactly. An illusion placed in our minds by this planet's  inhabitants.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: They may simply be studying the Captain, to find out how Earth  people are put together. Or it could be something more.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Look. Brains three times the size of ours. If we start buzzing  about down there, we're liable to find their mental power is so great  they could reach out and swat this ship as though it were a fly.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: We've located a magnetic field that seems to  come from their underground generator.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: If our measurements and readings are an illusion also, one could  find oneself materialised inside solid rock.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: The women!

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Address intercraft.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: This is the acting captain speaking. We have no choice now but  to consider the safety of this vessel and the remainder of the crew.  We're leaving. All decks prepare for hyperdrive. Time warp factor.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Engine room!

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Mister Spock here. Switch to rockets. We're blasting out.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Nothing. But for the batteries we'd lose gravitation and oxygen.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Could be we've waited too long. It's collecting all the  information stored in this fly. They've decided to swat us.

title: The  Cage Unaired  pilot
dialogue: Mister Spock here.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Your move, Captain.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: I'll have you checkmated your next move.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Irritating? Ah, yes. One of your Earth emotions.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: The fact one of my ancestors married a human female

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Not large enough even for a lifeboat.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: More like destroyed the ship in this case. Look at it. Burnt,  pitted.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: He played most illogically. His next move should have been the  rook.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: The tapes are burnt out. Trying the memory banks.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Getting something from the recorder now.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Decoding memory banks. I'll try to interpolate. The Valiant had  encountered a magnetic space storm and was being swept in this  direction.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Swept past this point, about a half light year out of the  galaxy, they were thrown clear, turned, and headed back into the galaxy  here. I'm not getting it all. The tapes are pretty badly burned. Sounds  like the ship had encountered some unknown force. Now, orders, counter  orders, repeated urgent requests for information from the ship's  computer records for anything concerning ESP in human beings.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Severe damage. Seven crewmen dead. No, make that six. One  crewman seemed to have recovered. That's when they became interested in  extrasensory perception. More than interested, almost frantic about it.  No, this must be garbled. I get something about destruct. I must have  read it wrong. It sounded like the captain giving an order to destroy  his own ship.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Force field of some kind.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Sensor beam on.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Deflectors full intensity.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Deflectors say there's something there, sensors say there isn't.  Density negative. Radiation negative. Energy negative.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Negative!

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Damage control reports, all stations!

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Main engines are out, sir. We're on emergency power cells.  Casualties, nine dead.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: I think we've found that answer, Doctor.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Before the Valiant was destroyed, its captain was frantically  searching for ESP information on his crew.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Are there not also those who seem to see through solid objects,  cause fires to start spontaneously?

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Doctor Dehner is speaking of normal ESP power.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: He's reading even faster now than just a few  moments ago. Is that Gary Mitchell, the one you used to know?

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Our subject is not Gary Mitchell. Our concern is, rather, what  he is mutating into.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Have you noted evidence of unusual powers?

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: And on my monitor screen I could see Mitchell smiling each time  it happened, as if this ship and crew were almost a toy for his  amusement.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: In less time than that, he will have attained powers we can't  understand and can't cope with. Soon we'll be not only useless to him,  but actually an annoyance.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: We'll never reach an Earth base with him aboard, Jim. You heard  the mathematics of it. In a month he'll have as much in common with us  as we'd have with a ship full of white mice.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Recommendation one. There's a planet a few light days away from  here. Delta Vega. It has a lithium cracking station. We may be able to  adapt some of its power packs to our engines.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: It is the only possible way to get Mitchell off this ship.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Then you have one other choice. Kill Mitchell while you still  can.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: It is your only other choice, assuming you make it while you  still have time.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: The captain of the Valiant probably felt the same way, and he  waited too long to make his decision. I think we've both guessed that.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: He's regaining consciousness.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Fighting the force field drained his strength, for a while at  least. He could be handled now.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: He tried to get through the force field again. His eyes changed  back faster. He didn't become as weak.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: Because she feels. I don't. All I know is logic. In my opinion  we'll be lucky if we can repair this ship and get away in time.

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: If he should try to stop us

title: Where  No Man Has Gone Before
dialogue: I felt for him, too.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver

dialogue: It does sound most inconvenient, however. Have you considered  having it removed?

dialogue: Reporting, sir. Sensors show it is solid,  but its composition is unknown to us.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: I believe it adds up to either one of two possibilities. First,  a space buoy of some kind.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Flypaper.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Negative. It would make us appear too weak.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Radiation from the short end of the spectrum increasing.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Radiation increasing.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Radiation nearing the tolerance level.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Radiation at the tolerance level.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Radiation passing the tolerance level, entering lethal zone.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Growing. We can take only a few more seconds of this.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Nothing, Captain. No contacts, no objects in  any direction.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Speculate? No. Logically, we'll discover the intelligence which  sent out the cube.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Probably both, and if you're asking the logical decision to make

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Has it occurred to you that there's a certain inefficiency in  constantly questioning me on things you've already made up your mind  about?

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Exceptionally strong contact. Not visual  yet. Distant spectrograph. Metallic, similar to cube. Much greater  energy reading.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Tractor beam, Captain. Something's grabbed us, hard.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Reading goes off my scale, Captain. Must be a mile in diameter.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Captain, we're being invaded by exceptionally strong sensor  probes everywhere. Our electrical systems, our engines.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: They're shutting off some of our systems, Captain. Brilliant.  Extremely sophisticated in their methods.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Enough to warn other Earth ships.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Marker on course. Heading back the way we

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Might be interesting to see what they look like if I can locate  where that voice is coming from.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Switching to screen. I believe I can get something visual.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: I was curious to see how they appeared.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Jim.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: They're certainly aware by now that we're totally incapable of  it.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: In chess, when one is outmatched, the game is over. Checkmate.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: I'm s, I regret that I can find no other logical alternative.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: However, it was well played. I regret not having learned more  about this Balok. In some manner he was reminiscent of my father.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Quite the contrary. She considered herself a very fortunate  Earth woman.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: A very interesting game, this poker.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: I have visual contact, Captain.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: About two thousand metric tons.

dialogue: Engine systems coming on, Captain.

dialogue: Tractor beam again.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: He's sneaked power down a bit.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: We're superheating. Intermix temperature, seven thousand four  hundred degrees. Seven five, seven six, eight thousand degrees.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: Two thousand degrees above maximum. Eight four, eight five,  eight six. She'll blow soon!

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: That may not be wise. He got a signal through to the mother ship.

title: The  Corbomite Maneuver
dialogue: For it, Captain?

dialogue: Captain, request permission to

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Difficult to say, Captain. We're getting no registration beam  from it.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Sir, he's pushing his engines too hard.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Approaching an asteroid belt, Captain. Schiller rating three  five.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Sensor reading on the vessel. I make it out as a small class J  cargo ship, and his engines are super-heating.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: How many more in your crew?

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: What's wrong?

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: It'll take longer on battery power.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Curious. You're certain this was everyone aboard, Mister Walsh?  No other crewmen?

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: You can explain that to the Captain.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Deck twelve.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: The Commander of the transport to see you, Captain.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: I'm well aware of that, Mister Scott.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Better rig a by-pass circuit.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Needed on the bridge, Captain.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: The entire ship's power is feeding through  one lithium crystal.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: And that crystal won't hold up, not pulling all our power  through it.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: There's a lithium mining operation on Rigel 12. High-grade ore,  I've heard.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Mister Farrell has the course. Less than two day's travel.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Rigel 12, Mister Farrell. You have the course.   Captain's log, Stardate 1329.2. On board the U.S.S.  Enterprise, a ship's hearing is being convened against the transport  vessel's captain. I'm becoming concerned about the almost-hypnotic  effect produced by the women.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: State your name for the record.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Your correct name.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: State your correct name for the record.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Any past offenses, Mister Mudd?

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: We can sustain this orbit for three days, seven hours.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Even burned and cracked, they're beautiful.  Destroying them was a shame.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Conserving batteries, sir. Half power.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: We don't have the time to spare, Captain.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: The storm is ionising the atmosphere, Captain. Getting difficult  to probe through it.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Infrared reading. Check traverse three, grid  zero four zero.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: There's a heat unit operating in there. It could be a cookstove.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: Mudd?

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: I'm happy the affair is over. A most annoying emotional episode.

title: Mudd's  Women
dialogue: The fact that my internal arrangement differs from yours,  Doctor, pleases me no end.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Is there something I can do for you, Captain?

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Well, Doctor McCoy seemed to think I should check on you.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Well, our good doctor said that you were acting like a wild man,  demanded brandy.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Hmm. Well, in that case, if you'll excuse the intrusion Captain,  I'll get back to my work.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Captain.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Doctor McCoy reports that you demanded this brandy in Sickbay  and left with it. I found this bottle in Yeoman Rand's quarters.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: You can go now, Yeoman.  There's only one logical  answer. We have an impostor aboard.   Captain's Log, stardate 1672.9. On the planet's  surface, temperatures are beginning to drop, our landing party there in  growing jeopardy. Due to the malfunction of the ship's transporter, an  unexplained duplicate of myself definitely exists.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: About your double, Captain.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: We can't take a chance on killing it. We have no previous  experience, no way of knowing what would happen to you.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: How shall we explain it to them, Captain? The search parties are  to capture you?

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: The search parties, Captain.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Captain, no disrespect intended, but you must surely realise you  can't announce the full truth to the crew. You're the Captain of this  ship. You haven't the right to be vulnerable in the eyes of the crew.  You can't afford the luxury of being anything less than perfect. If you  do, they lose faith, and you lose command.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Understood, Captain.   Captain's Log, stardate 1673.1. Something has  happened to me. Somehow, in being duplicated, I have lost my strength  of will.  Decisions are becoming more and more difficult.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: About the phaser weapons to be set for stunning force and  locked.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Thermal heaters were transported down. They duplicated. They  won't operate.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Spock here.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Acknowledged. Continue the search.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Apparently, this double, however different in temperament, has  your knowledge of the ship, its crew, its devices. This being the case,  perhaps we can outguess him by determining his next move. Knowing how  the ship is laid out, where would you go to elude a mass search?

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Set and locked on base cycle to stun, not to  kill. What about your phaser, Captain? Don't you think we ought to get  some help, Captain?

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Captain, you ordered me to tell you.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Judging from my observations, Captain, you're rapidly losing the  power of decision.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Yes, always, Doctor. We have here an unusual opportunity to  appraise the human mind, or to examine, in Earth terms,  the roles of good and evil in a man. His negative side, which you call  hostility, lust, violence, and his positive side, which Earth people  express as compassion, love, tenderness.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Yes, and what is it that makes one man an exceptional leader? We  see indications that it's his negative side  which makes him strong, that his evil side, if you will, properly  controlled and disciplined, is vital to his strength. Your negative  side removed from you, the power of command begins to elude you.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: If your power of command continues to weaken, you'll soon be  unable to function as Captain. You must be prepared for that.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: If I seem insensitive to what you're going through, Captain,  understand it's the way I am.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: This is Spock, Mister Sulu. You'll have to  hold on a little longer. There's no other way. Survival procedures,  Mister Sulu.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: We've attached some bypass and leader circuits to compensate for  the difference. Tied directly into the impulse engines, there shouldn't  be more than a five point variation in the velocity balance. I suggest  we send the animal through.  Captain.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: It's painless and quick. The animal will be unconscious for only  a few minutes.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Energise. Reverse.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: The shock of putting him back together seems to have been too  much for him.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: For once, I agree with you.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: No autopsy is necessary to know that the animal was terrified,  confused. It was split into two halves and suddenly thrust back  together again. Thus shock induced by blind terror.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: It couldn't understand. You can. You have your intelligence  controlling your fear.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Aren't you forgetting something, Captain?

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Your men on the planet surface. How much time do they have left?

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Being split in two halves is no theory with me, Doctor. I have a  human half, you see, as well as an alien half, submerged, constantly at  war with each other. Personal experience, Doctor. I survive it because  my intelligence wins over both, makes them live together. Your  intelligence would enable you to survive as well.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Are you relinquishing your command, Captain?

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Captain, I thought the plan   OTHER

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: We'll let the captain handle this.   OTHER

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: You'll have to hold on to him, Captain.

dialogue: Captain?

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Understood, Captain.

dialogue: Ready.

title: The  Enemy WIthin
dialogue: Right away, Captain.

dialogue: All sections report ready, sir.

dialogue: Shall I pass that on to the crew, sir?

title: The  Enemy WIthin

title: The  Man Trap

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Cry?

dialogue: Well, since it is illogical for a communications officer to  resent the word frequency, I have no answer.

dialogue: Vulcan has no moon, Miss Uhura.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Bridge acknowledging.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Explain.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Lieutenant, my demonstration of concern will not change what  happened. The transporter room is very well-manned and they will call  if they need my assistance.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: No mistake in our record tapes. Borgia plant. Its sole deadly  property is alkaloid poison.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Check out perfectly. They arrived here nearly five years ago.  Visited by various vessels, made fairly heavy shipments out, of  artefacts and reports. However, there has been a marked drop in  shipments during the last year.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Sodium chloride. Not a trace of it.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: He would die almost instantly.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Something odd, Captain. You said two people.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: We get a reading on only one person, probably Crater. He's  circling as if searching for something.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Yes, sir.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: The simple fact is unless there's something seriously wrong with  the ship's equipment, there's only one person within a one hundred mile  circle.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Spock cutting in, Captain. Something here, through the arches to  your left.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Green.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Or something did.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Crater knows the creature. If we could take him alive.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Obviously, taking him alive is going to be difficult.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Why risk your life for his?

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Acknowledged. Crater!

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: The Earth buffalo. What about it?

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: And now they're gone. Is that what you mean?

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Always in the past tense.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Supplies of salt have been set out as bait at all decks and  engineering levels, Captain. However, no one or nothing has approached  them as yet.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Your attitude is laudable, Doctor, but your reasoning is  reckless.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: A very interesting hypothesis, Doctor. Briefing room.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Recommend we use truth serum, Captain.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: I'll accompany you, Doctor.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: It wasn't McCoy. It was the creature. It hit me.  Crater grabbed my phaser. I wondered about McCoy. Doubt had crossed my  mind.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Fortunately, my ancestors spawned in another ocean than yours  did. My blood cells are quite different.

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: It's killing the Captain. Shoot it, Doctor, quickly!

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: This is not Nancy.  If she were Nancy,  could she take this?

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Is that Nancy, Doctor?

title: The  Man Trap
dialogue: Something wrong, Captain?

title: The  Naked Time
dialogue: Check out the life-support systems.

title: The  Naked Time
dialogue: Someone strangled this woman.  TORMOLEN The other four are back there.

title: The  Naked Time
dialogue: Dead?

title: The  Naked Time
dialogue: Engineer at his post?  TORMOLEN He's frozen there like he didn't care.

title: The  Naked Time
dialogue: The rest?

title: The  Naked Time
dialogue: Be certain we expose ourselves to nothing. Spock here. Do you  read, Enterprise?

title: The  Naked Time
dialogue: All station personnel are dead.

title: The  Naked Time
dialogue: Unknown, Captain. It's like nothing we've dealt with before.   Captain's Log: Stardate 1704.2. The science party  we were to have picked up has been found dead. Life support systems had  been turned off. Station personnel, frozen to death. Conditions highly  unusual. Meanwhile, we remain in orbit to complete our mission, close  scientific measurement of the break-up of this planet.

title: The  Naked Time

dialogue: He came up from engineering, Captain.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Any explanation? He's a fine young officer. He's bound to  consider this transfer a disciplinary action.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Spare me your philosophical metaphors, Doctor. The Captain is  acting strangely. I'm asking if you've noticed.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: My father's race was spared the dubious benefits of alcohol.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: It occurred. I dismissed it.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Did you know that he suddenly transferred Lieutenant Riley to  engineering?

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: No, thank you.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Full personal dossiers on the following names. Doctor Thomas  Leighton, Anton Karidian, Lieutenant Kevin Riley, and Captain James T.  Kirk.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Correlate. Check their past histories. Report any item, any past  episode or experience they all have in common.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: I will continue, Doctor. According to our library banks, it  started on the Earth colony of Tarsus Four, when the food supply was  attacked by an exotic fungus and largely destroyed. There were over  eight thousand colonists and virtually no food. And that was when  Governor Kodos seized full power and declared emergency martial law.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: You may not have heard it all. Kodos began to separate the  colonists. Some would live, be rationed whatever food was left. The  remainder would be immediately put to death. Apparently he had his own  theories of eugenics.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Perhaps not. But he was certainly among the most ruthless, to  decide arbitrarily who would survive and who would not, using his own  personal standards, and then to implement his decision without mercy.  Children watching their parents die. Whole families destroyed. Over  four thousand people. They died quickly, without pain, but they died.  Relief arrived, but too late to prevent the executions. And Kodos?  There never was a positive identification of his body.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: His history begins almost to the day where Kodos disappeared.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: He'd better. There were nine eye witnesses who survived the  massacre, who'd actually seen Kodos with their own eyes. Jim Kirk was  one of them.  With the exception of Riley and Captain Kirk, every other eye witness  is dead. And my library computer shows that wherever they were, on  Earth, on a colony, or aboard ship, the Karidian Company of Players was  somewhere near when they died.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: You've got to pull him through.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: If he dies, the only one who'll be able to identify Kodos is the  Captain. And he'll be the next target.  Captain's log, stardate 2819.1. Ship's officer  Riley's condition worsening. Doctor McCoy making lab analysis to  determine cause and antidote. Entire crew deeply concerned.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Someone tried to poison him.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: I don't believe that and neither do you. I want the Captain to  see that report.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Now.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Can we predict the same for you, Captain?

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Lieutenant Riley was a witness. So were you.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Someone tried to kill him.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: You should be told the difference between empiricism and  stubbornness, Doctor. I checked with the library computer, just as you  did. I got the same information.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Is my personal business when it might interfere with the smooth  operation of this ship.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: It could happen.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Even in this corner of the galaxy, Captain, two plus two equals  four. Almost certainly an attempt will be made to kill you. Why do you  invite death?

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: He is.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Logic, Captain. Doctor Leighton was murdered while the Karidian  Company was on Planet Q. Now an attempt has been made against Riley  while the company is on board the Enterprise.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Shh. Listen. Do you hear it? That low hum.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: On overload.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: You can't stay.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Evacuate this section. Seal it off. Clear  section C4 and C5.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: I believe we have a match, Captain.

title: The  Conscience of the King
dialogue: Ready to leave Benecia orbit, Captain.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Power up. All instruments activated. All readings normal. All  go.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Position?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Make up your mind please, Mister Latimer.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Considerably, Mister Boma.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Stop forward momentum, Mister Latimer.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Galileo to Enterprise. Galileo to Enterprise. Come in, please.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Galileo to Enterprise. Galileo to Enterprise. We are out of  control, being pulled directly into the heart of Murasaki three one  two. Being hit by violent radiation on outer hull. Course three point  two five

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I'd say your evaluation is reasonable, Mister Boma.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Picturesque descriptions will not mend broken circuits, Mister  Scott. I think you'll find your work is cut out for you. Galileo to  Enterprise. Galileo to Enterprise. Come in, please.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I expect nothing, Mister Scott. It is merely logical to try all  the alternatives. Doctor McCoy, a reading on the atmosphere, please.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Just the facts, Doctor.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Thank you for your opinion. It will be duly noted. You're  recording this, Yeoman?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Mister Scott, if you'll make a survey of the damage, please.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Gentlemen, I think we should move outside, make room for Mister  Scott to do his work. Mister Latimer, Mister Gaetano, you'll arm  yourselves and scout out the area, keeping in visual contact with the  ship.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Under present conditions, extremely poor.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: If the ionisation effect is as widespread as I believe it is,  Doctor, they'll be searching for us without instrumentation, by visual  contact only. On those terms, this is a very large planet.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Not as long as we're grounded. We may be here for a very long  time, Doctor.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: My big chance? For what, Doctor?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I am a logical man, Doctor.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Perhaps, Doctor, but I know of no better way to begin. I realise  command does have its fascinations, even under circumstances such as  these. But I neither enjoy the idea of command, nor am I frightened of  it. It simply exists. And I will do whatever logically needs to be  done.  Excuse me.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: In what way?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: The weight of three grown men.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Doctor McCoy, with very few exceptions we use virtually every  piece of equipment aboard this craft in attaining orbit. There's very  little excess weight, except among the passengers.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Unless the situation changes radically, yes.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: As commanding officer, the choice will be mine.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: A very quaint idea, Mister Boma, but I do believe I'm better  qualified to make the selection than any random drawing of lots.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: My choice will be a logical one, arrived at through logical  means.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: But attaining a desired goal always is, Doctor. Now gentlemen, I  suggest we move outside to make a further examination of the hull in  the event we've overlooked any minor damage.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Come on, Boma.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: What was it?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Nothing there.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I don't doubt your word.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Folsom Point.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: There's a remarkable resemblance to the Folsom Point discovered  in 1925, old world calendar, New Mexico, North America. A bit more  crude about the shaft, I believe. Not very efficient.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Am I in error, Mister Boma?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Then what, Mister Boma?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: My concern for the dead will not bring him back to life, Mister  Boma.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Bringing him back to the ship should not interfere with our  repair efforts. If you need assistance, I

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Perhaps if you were to channel the second  auxiliary tank through the primary intake valve.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Excellent, Doctor.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Which would still leave us at least one hundred and fifty pounds  overweight.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: It is more rational to sacrifice one life than six, Doctor.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: You might be wise to start.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: For what?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Mister Boma, we're working against time.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Doctor, perhaps you know the correct words for such an occasion.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: My place is here. If you please, Doctor.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: By dealing with first things first, I hope to increase our  chances of staying alive. Well, Mister Scott.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: What happened?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: That would seem to solve the problem of who to leave behind.  Consider the alternatives, Mister Scott.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Mister Scott, there are always alternatives.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Wood rubbing on some kind of leather.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Not a tribal culture. Their artefacts are too primitive. More  likely a loose association of some sort.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: How, Mister Boma?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I'm frequently appalled by the low regard you Earthmen have for  life.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Mister Boma?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Doctor McCoy?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: It does, indeed. It seems logical to me, also. But to take life  indiscriminately,

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I am not interested in the opinion of the majority, Mister  Gaetano. Components must be weighed. Our danger to ourselves as well as  our duties to other life forms, friendly or not. There's a third  course.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I think not. Doctor McCoy.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: You and Yeoman Mears return to the ship. Assist Mister Scott in  any way possible. We'll be back shortly.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Gentlemen, you'll follow my orders to the letter, firing only  when so instructed, and at my designated targets.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: We'll fire to frighten, Mister Gaetano, not to kill.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I am in command, Mister Gaetano. The orders and the  responsibility will be mine. Follow me.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I hear them. They're directly ahead of us. Several, I believe.  Direct your phasers to two o'clock and to ten o'clock.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Yes, I know. But fortunately, I'm giving the orders. Take aim  please, and fire when I give a signal.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Fire.  Cease fire.   They should think twice before bothering us again.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: It was not necessary. Fear will do for us what needs to be done.  Mister Boma, you will return with me to the Galileo. Mister Gaetano,  you remain on guard here. Keep in contact with the ship.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Yes, we found them. They won't bother us again.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Go, Mister Scott.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: That's all very well, but we don't have a substitute supply.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: They would also seem to be our only hope.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Yeoman, your phaser.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: They won't attack for at least several hours. By then, with  luck, we'll be gone.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: We don't have to maintain it very long, Mister Scott. In less  than twenty four hours, the Enterprise will be forced to abandon its  search in order to make a rendezvous. If we can't maintain orbit after  that time, it won't make any difference. If we burn up in a decaying  orbit or die here on the planet's surface, we shall surely die. Doctor,  your phaser. Go to work, Mister Scott.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Take this back to Mister Scott for conversion, please Doctor.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: And give this to Mister Scott in  the event I don't return.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I have a certain scientific curiosity about what's become of  Mister Gaetano. Return to the ship, please.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Most illogical reaction. We demonstrated our superior weapons.  They should have fled.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Of course.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Doctor, I am not responsible for their unpredictability.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: They're studying us, for the moment.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: My opinion, Mister Boma.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Seal the windows!

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Mister Boma, your tone is increasingly hostile.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Curious. Most illogical.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Strange. Step by step, I have made the correct and logical  decisions. And yet two men have died.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I do seem to have miscalculated regarding them, and inculcated  resentment on your parts. The sum of the parts cannot be greater than  the whole.   MCCOY A little less analysis and more action. That's what we need,  Mister Spock.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: How much longer, Mister Scott?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Mister Scott, how much power do we have left  in the ship's batteries?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Will they electrify the exterior of this ship?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Get to the centre of the ship. Don't touch the plates. Be sure  you're insulated. Stand by. Are you ready, Scott?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: All right. Go.  Again! Again!

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I believe we've used enough. Mister Scott. I suggest you  continue draining the phasers.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: For the moment.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: The moment they discover they're not seriously hurt, they'll be  back. Meanwhile, please check the aft compartment. See if there's  anything you can unload to lighten the ship.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: It will of course have to be left behind.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I wouldn't recommend it. The creatures won't be far away.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: It would expose members of this crew to unnecessary peril.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Gentlemen. All right, Mister Boma, you'll have your burial,  provided the creatures will permit it.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: How about weight?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: And how long can we hold it?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: To land here again? Not a very attractive possibility.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Doctor McCoy. Mister Boma. When can we lift off, Scott?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Gentlemen, The ship will lift off in exactly ten minutes. You  have that long to bury Mister Gaetano. Now, it appears to be clear  outside, at least for the moment. I'll assist you. Hurry.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Get into the ship! Immediate lift off!

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: No! Go back! Lift off! Go back! No!

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: All right, All right! Go! Go! Go! Go!

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Go, Scott!

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: I told you to lift off!

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Get us off, Scott!

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Quite right, Mister Scott. There's somebody holding us down. All  systems are go, but we're not moving.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Our boosters.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Would you rather stay here?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: May I remind you we have yet to achieve orbit, nor can we  maintain it long. An hour from now we may be right back where we  started from.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Gentlemen, by coming after me, you may well have destroyed what  slim chance you had for survival. The logical thing for you to have  done was to have left me behind.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: That is a most illogical attitude. Orbit in one minute, Mister  Scott. Fuel status?

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: It is the usual end of a decaying orbit.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Infinitely preferable to the kind of death we'd be granted on  the planet's surface, I should think.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Did l? I may have been mistaken.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: The Enterprise is surely on course for Makus Three by now. I for  one do not believe in angels.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Yes. My first command.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Galileo to Enterprise. Galileo to Enterprise, come in, please.  Galileo to Enterprise. Come in, please.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Perhaps, Mister Boma.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: No one out there to see it.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Totally illogical. There was no chance.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Captain.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Quite correct, Captain.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Quite simply, Captain. I examined the problem from all angles,  and it was plainly hopeless. Logic informed me that under the  circumstances, the only possible action would have to be one of  desperation. Logical decision, logically arrived at.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Well, I wouldn't put it in exactly those terms, Captain, but  those are essentially the facts.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: No, sir.

title: The  Galileo Seven
dialogue: Yes, sir.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Captain, I believe I

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Miss Finney, come with me, please.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: I know all about them.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Affirmative.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Negative.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Affirmative.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: But the computer is inaccurate, never the less.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: It reports that the jettison button was pressed before the Red  Alert.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: And that is impossible.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: No, I was occupied. The ship was already on Yellow Alert.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: I do not dispute it. I merely state that it is wrong.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: I know the Captain. He is in

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Lieutenant, I am half Vulcanian. Vulcanians do not speculate. I  speak from pure logic. If I let go of a hammer on a planet that has a  positive gravity, I need not see it fall to know that it has in fact  fallen.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Gentlemen, human beings have characteristics just as inanimate  objects do. It is impossible for Captain Kirk to act out of panic or  malice. It is not his nature.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Yes. In my opinion.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Mister Finney is top of duty roster, Captain.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Attention, Commander Finney, report to pod for reading on ion  plates.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Officer posted, Captain.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Acknowledged.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Captain.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: I've run a complete megalyte survey on the  computer.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: You sound bitter, Captain.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Further instructions?

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Chess.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Explain.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: That is true.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Why, thank you, Doctor. I've just won my fourth game.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Observe for yourself. Rook to king's pawn four.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Now, this is the computer's move. And now mine.  Checkmate. Mechanically, the computer's flawless. Therefore,  logically, its report of the captain's guilt is infallible. I could not  accept that, however.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Exactly. I programmed it myself for chess some months ago. The  best I should have been able to attain was a draw.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Transporter room, stand by. We're beaming down.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Five in all.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Affirmative.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: I personally programmed the computer for chess months ago. I  gave the machine an understanding of the game equal to my own. The  computer cannot make an error and assuming that I do not either, the  best that could normally be hoped for would be stalemate after  stalemate, and yet I beat the machine five times. Someone, either  accidentally or deliberately, adjusted the programming and therefore  the memory banks of that computer.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Affirmative.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: The Captain, myself, and the records officer.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Affirmative. Until he was lost, our records officer was  Lieutenant Commander Finney.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Affirmative, Captain.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: B deck, in or near Engineering.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Acknowledged.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Compensate.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Decaying, Captain.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Gentlemen, if you'll please hurry to the transporter room

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Very well, sir.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Activate port impulse engines. One third power.

title: Court  Martial
dialogue: Obviously.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Eleven years, four months, five days.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Captain Pike, may I remain for a moment?  You know why I've come, Captain. It's only six days away at  maximum warp and I have it well-planned.  I have never  disobeyed your orders before, Captain, but this time I must.   I know. I know it is treachery and it's mutiny. but I must do this.   I have no choice.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: I have security clearance, Chief.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: This is Mister Spock.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: You will not discuss this with ship's crew  or starbase personnel. Do you read?

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Stand by. We'll warp out of orbit in one  hour.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: The Enterprise knows where she's going, Mister Hansen.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Maintain radio silence, Lieutenant. This is First Officer Spock.  Per Starfleet orders this date, I have been placed in temporary command  of the Enterprise. While our destination is secret, our mission is  relatively simple. Starbase Command has assigned Captain Kirk medical  rest leave until our return. His instructions are that you will obey my  orders as you would his. First Officer out.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: And no one from the ship made such a call.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Doctor, I regret they elected to keep certain things from you.  Will you come with me, please.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Doctor, one moment, please.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Take no action, Mister Hansen.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: You have your orders, Mister Hansen. We'll make no contact.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Lock on to sensors. Measure object now following the Enterprise.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Stop. How long before shuttlecraft's fuel supply forces return  to starbase?

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Computer control. Lock on to shuttlecraft following us.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Go to tape Abel Seven Baker. Execute instructions.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: This is the First Officer speaking. Security, send an armed team  to the Bridge. Transporter Room, stand by to beam Captain Kirk aboard.  Effective until then, Lieutenant Hansen is in operational command.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: First Officer out. Doctor, as senior officer present, I present  myself to you for arrest.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: The charge is mutiny, Doctor. I never received orders to take  command.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Doctor.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Adequate, Doctor. I'll make no trouble.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Sir, I waive counsel. Further, I waive rights to this hearing  and request immediate court-martial.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: May I inquire on what grounds, Captain?

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Sir, I must point out that there are three officers of command  rank available. Yourself, Commodore Mendez, and Captain Christopher  Pike.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: I believe you'll find he's still on the active duty list.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: I am.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Are your comments a part of the record, sir?

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Thank you. Request monitor screen be engaged.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: To comply with the request you just made, sir, that I explain  the importance of going to Talos Four.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: This is thirteen years ago. The Enterprise and its commander,  Captain Christopher Pike.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: I cannot tell you at this time, sir.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Unless the court asks a prisoner why, Commodore. You did ask  that question.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: As I stated, gentlemen, this was thirteen years ago. We were on  routine patrol when the ship's sensors detected something ahead. At  first we were not certain what it was.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Their call letters check with a survey expedition. S.S. Columbia  disappeared in that region approximately eighteen years ago.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Records show the Talos group has never been explored. Solar  system similar to Earth, eleven planets. Number four seems to be Class  M, oxygen atmosphere.  NUMBER

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: We aren't going to go, to be certain?

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Captain, please tell the court this is not imagination, nor some  clever photographic record. Are we seeing the actual events of thirteen  years ago?  Yes, gentlemen. On that screen as it happened, the  incredible experience of Captain Christopher Pike on Talos Four. If,  after witnessing this, the court wishes to turn this vessel back, I  will release this ship to manual control.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Preliminary lab survey ready, sir.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Yes, sir.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Are coming from Talos Four, sir.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: The Commodore must be aware that Captain Kirk knew nothing of  this.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Sir, I respectfully decline.

title: The  Menagerie, part 1
dialogue: Captain, Jim, please don't stop me. Don't let him stop me. It's  your career and Captain Pike's life. You must see the rest of the  transmission.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: They should be sending up a report momentarily, Captain.  Something wrong?

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Doctor McCoy is correct, Captain. After what this ship has been  through in the last three months, there is not a crewman aboard who is  not in need of rest. Myself excepted, of course.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Not necessary in my case, Captain. On my planet, to rest is to  rest, to cease using energy. To me, it is quite illogical to run up and  down on green grass using energy instead of saving it.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Very well, Captain. Something I did come to discuss.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: I picked this up from Doctor McCoy's log. We have a crewmember  aboard who's showing signs of stress and fatigue. Reaction time down  nine to twelve percent, associational reading norm minus three.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: He's becoming irritable and quarrelsome, yet he refuses to take  rest and rehabilitation. Now, He has that right, but we've found

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: James Kirk. Enjoy yourself, Captain. It's an interesting planet.  You'll find it quite pleasant. Very much like your Earth.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: I'm getting strange readings from the planet  surface, Captain. Some sort of power field down there.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Could be coming from beneath the planet's  surface. Patterns indicate some sort of industrial activity.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Any chance these could be hallucinations?

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: That sounds like a painful reality.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Your signal is very weak. Can you turn up  your gain?

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Captain, shall I beam down an armed party?

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Necessary, Captain. Unable to contact you by communicator, and  the transporter is useless to us now. As I told you before, there's an  unusual power field down here. It's soaking up all the energy at the  source. I calculated the rate of its growth, and reasoned that I just  might be able to transport one more person.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: This is not human skin tissue, Captain. It more closely  resembles the cellular casting we use for wound repairs. Much finer, of  course.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: This is definitely a mechanical contrivance. It has the same  basic cell structure as the plants here, even the trees, the grass.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: I'm saying that these are all multicellular castings. The  plants, the animals, the people. They're all being manufactured.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: All we know for certain is that they act exactly like the real  thing. Just as pleasant or just as deadly.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: At this point, Captain, my analysis may not sound very  scientific.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: There is one slight possibility, very slim, but nevertheless.  Captain, what were your thoughts just before you encountered the people  you described?

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Captain, wait.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Did you enjoy it, Captain?

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Which supports a theory I've been formulating.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Yes. Somehow our thoughts are read, these things are quickly  manufactured and provided for us.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Yes. We must all control our thoughts.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: The force field we encountered is obviously underground,  manufacturing these things. Passages lead to the surface. Just for  example, when Rodriguez thought of a tiger

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Captain.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: The term is amusement park.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: An old Earth name for a place where people could go to see and  do all sorts of fascinating things.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: I tend to agree.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Captain, I'll go back aboard  ship and take over. With all due respect to the young lady, I've  already had as much shore leave as I care for.

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Did you enjoy your rest, gentlemen?

title: Shore  Leave
dialogue: Most illogical.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Gravimetric readings, no significant change, zero space density.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: The precise meaning of the word desert is a waterless, barren  wasteland. I fail to understand your romantic nostalgia for such a  place.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Thank you, Doctor McCoy. Moving on schedule into quadrant nine  oh four. Beta Six is eight days distant.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Unusual, Captain. I'm now getting a sizable space-displacement  reading.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Inconceivable this body has gone unnoted on all our records.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Emergency! Full reverse power!   Ship's log Stardate 2124.5. First Officer Spock  reporting for Captain James Kirk. We are orbiting the lone unrecorded  planet in the star desert. For four hours, we have made every possible  instrument sweep, but Captain Kirk and Helmsman Sulu remain unaccounted  for. I have placed the ship on red alert.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Function is normal. Continuous sensor sweeps. Lieutenant Uhura,  have you checked all wave bands?

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: The decision will be mine, Doctor. I have the responsibility for  your safety.  Mister Jaeger, describe your  geophysical findings for the surface below.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Estimate survival time of two unprotected individuals down  there.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Greetings and felicitations. Hmm. Send this, Lieutenant. USS  Enterprise to signaler on planet surface. Identify self.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Hip hip hoorah? And I believe it's pronounced tally ho.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: I'll entertain any theories, Mister DeSalle. Any at all.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: You're quite correct, Doctor. Prepare transporter room.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: No, Mister Scott. Neither you nor I can be spared here. Mister  DeSalle, equip the landing party with full communications, armament,  and life-support gear. Mister Jaeger, your geophysical knowledge may be  crucial down there. Doctor McCoy will accompany. If those peculiar  signals are coming from Captain Kirk or Lieutenant Sulu, their  rationality is in question. Dismissed.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Very good. Transmit coordinates to Mister Scott. Once on the  planet's surface, you'll establish contact with us immediately. Use the  laser beacon if necessary. Ready, Scott?

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Activate.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: I don't, Mister Scott. It simply exists. Artificial perhaps, or  a freak of nature. The fact remains that life can exist in that area.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Apply a fine tuning on our sensors. Locate any life forms in  that stable area.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Affirmative. But if the Captain is down there and alive, that's  where he'll have to be. We'll attempt to transport up any living beings  our sensors detect.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Or stand by and do nothing, Mister Scott.       And this, of course, is an array of your battle flags and pennants  dating back to the Crusades, to Hannibal's invaders, the Grecian war  galleys, and the hordes of Persia. Can't you imagine it, Captain? The  thousands of men marching off to their deaths, singing beneath these  banners. Doesn't it make your blood run swiftly?

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: They didn't, Captain. Not clearly. We merely beamed up all life  forms in a given area.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: I am Spock.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: My father is from the planet Vulcan.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Not generally. But there have been exceptions.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Affirmative.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: I object to you. I object to intellect without discipline. I  object to power without constructive purpose.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: It may be unappetizing, Doctor, but it is very logical.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Fascinating is a word I use for the unexpected. In this case, I  should think interesting would suffice.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: That his food has no taste, his wine no flavour? No. It simply  means that Trelane knows all of the Earth forms, but none of the  substance.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Evidently.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Is it ego, or something else?

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: The mirror.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: You noted yourself he never gets very far from it. I suppose it  could be vanity.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: A machine with the ability to turn energy into matter guided by  thought waves. It would have a very complex memory bank, and would be  extremely sophisticated.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: I think not. A device capable of keeping out this planet's  natural atmosphere would be immense.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Free, Captain?

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Captain.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: The machine.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Can we know his range is, Captain?

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Collision course.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: That was the planet Gothos, Captain.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Gothos again, Captain.

dialogue: Cat and mouse game.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Or it toward us.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Captain.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: For the record, how do we describe him? Pure mentality? Force of  intellect? Embodied energy? Superbeing? He must be classified, sir.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: I hardly find that fitting.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: It will make a strange entry in the library banks.

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: Mischievous pranks, Captain?

title: The  Squire of Gothos
dialogue: I shall be delighted, Captain.

title: Arena
dialogue: Captain. I wonder why he's insistent that our tactical aides  come down.

title: Arena
dialogue: Perhaps, Captain, but nevertheless

title: Arena
dialogue: Doctor, you are a sensualist.

title: Arena
dialogue: Those messages we got, Captain, the one directing us here  yesterday.

title: Arena
dialogue: Captain, impulses that direction. Very weak, possibly a survivor.

title: Arena
dialogue: Getting another life reading, Captain.

title: Arena
dialogue: Not survivors. Not warm-blooded. Living creatures, but not human.

title: Arena
dialogue: Azimuth ninety three degrees, range one five seven zero yards.

dialogue: We're hopelessly outnumbered here, Captain. It's those  disruptors versus our hand phasers.

title: Arena
dialogue: Nor can they at us at the moment. Not unless they moved their  original position. That intervening high ground.

title: Arena
dialogue: About one hundred yards in that direction. But after an attack  as thorough as this one
