dialogue: How is he, Doctor?

title: Arena
dialogue: They're moving. I've got to get to the Captain.

title: Arena
dialogue: Locked on to the enemy, Captain. They're moving toward the high  ground.  They've locked on to my tricorder.

title: Arena
dialogue: Very ingenious. They fed back my own impulses and built up an  overload.

title: Arena
dialogue: Any word from the Enterprise?

title: Arena
dialogue: Very clever. As to the reason?

title: Arena
dialogue: You allude to invasion, Captain, yet positive proof

title: Arena
dialogue: Not necessarily, sir. Several possible explanations

title: Arena
dialogue: Very well, then. If that's the case, you must make certain that  the alien vessel never reaches its home base.

title: Arena
dialogue: Virtually nothing, Captain. No records of any explorations.  There are rumours of certain strange signals on subspace channels.  However, none has ever been recorded.

title: Arena
dialogue: Nothing specific, Captain. Unscientific rumours only. More like  space legends.

title: Arena
dialogue: A sustained warp seven speed will be dangerous, Captain.

title: Arena
dialogue: You mean to destroy the alien ship, Captain?

title: Arena
dialogue: I thought perhaps the hot pursuit alone might be sufficient.  Destruction might be unnecessary.

title: Arena
dialogue: The destruction of the alien vessel will not help that colony,  Jim.

title: Arena
dialogue: I merely suggested that a regard for sentient life

title: Arena
dialogue: Very clear, Captain.

title: Arena
dialogue: It would appear someone is curious about us.

title: Arena
dialogue: Computer lock ready, Captain. All systems standing by.

title: Arena
dialogue: Same as the alien, Captain.

title: Arena
dialogue: All systems report normal, Captain. No ascertainable damage.

title: Arena
dialogue: We're being held in place, Captain, apparently from that solar  system.

title: Arena
dialogue: We are being held.

title: Arena
dialogue: No, sir. An unidentifiable power.

title: Arena
dialogue: Have you tried overload?

title: Arena
dialogue: How about bypassing the transformer banks? Feed the impulse  engines directly.

title: Arena
dialogue: Lieutenant Uhura, have sensors learned anything about the nature  of the force which holds us here?

title: Arena
dialogue: No indication of its composition? Gravimetric? Magnetic?  Electronic?

title: Arena
dialogue: Leave channel one open, Lieutenant, just in  case.

title: Arena
dialogue: I'm going to wait, Doctor. There's little else I can do.

title: Arena
dialogue: If I could help him, I would. I cannot.

title: Arena
dialogue: He's out there, Doctor. Out there somewhere in a thousand cubic  parsecs of space, and there's absolutely nothing we can do to help him.

title: Arena
dialogue: This is the U.S.S. Enterprise calling the  Metrons. Our channels are open. Come in, please. We urgently desire a  conference. Please answer.

title: Arena
dialogue: But it has happened, Doctor.

title: Arena
dialogue: Yes, indeed, Doctor, if only there were. Notice the substance  encrusting that rock. Yes. Unless I'm mistaken, it's potassium nitrate.

title: Arena
dialogue: Perhaps nothing, Doctor.  Perhaps everything.

title: Arena
dialogue: It may well be possible, Doctor. We know very little about that  section of the galaxy.

title: Arena
dialogue: Perhaps. That is something best decided by diplomats.

title: Arena
dialogue: Yes.

title: Arena
dialogue: Fascinating. Good. Good.  He knows, Doctor. He has reasoned it out.

title: Arena
dialogue: Yes. Yes.

title: Arena
dialogue: An invention, Doctor. First potassium nitrate, and now if he can  find some sulphur and a charcoal deposit or ordinary coal.

title: Arena
dialogue: Diamonds. The hardest known substance. Impelled by sufficient  force, they would make formidable projectiles.

title: Arena
dialogue: Recall your basic chemistry, Doctor. Gunpowder.

title: Arena
dialogue: Coal.

title: Arena
dialogue: If he has the time, Doctor. If he has the time.

title: Arena
dialogue: After you touched off your primitive cannon, Captain, we lost  the picture the Metron was sending us.

title: Arena
dialogue: Most of it. I would be interested in knowing what finally  happened.

title: Arena
dialogue: I've frequently had my doubts.

title: Arena
dialogue: A thousand years, Captain?  Well, that gives us a little time.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Very typical, Captain. Iron-silicon base, oxygen-hydrogen  atmosphere, largely arid, no discernible life. No surprises.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Captain.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Incredible, Captain.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: What my instruments read is totally unbelievable, Captain.  Twice, for a split second each time, everything within range of our  instruments seemed on the verge of winking out.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: I have given you the facts, Captain. The entire magnetic field  in this solar system simply blinked. The planet below, the mass of  which we're measuring, attained zero gravity.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Is non-existence.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Captain, scanners now report a life object on the planet surface  below.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Inexplicable, Captain. This reading began at approximately the  moment that the pulsation phenomenon began to subside.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: A living being. Body temperature 98.5 Fahrenheit. Mass,  electrical impulses, movement. It is apparently human, Captain.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Almost to the second.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: None.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Possible. Very possible.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Negative, Captain. Scanners indicate situation normal.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Nothing. Illogical. An effect of such proportions, unexplainable  by any established physical laws that I'm aware of. I have been able to  ascertain one fact. Though the effect, whatever it was, was  unquestioningly widespread, it was strongest here on the planet beneath  us.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Third, a closer examination of the planet's surface would be in  order. My job, sir?

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Negative, Captain. Anything from our guest?

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Lieutenant Uhura communicated that information. I ordered  re-confirmation on our sensors. They indicate no living creature on  this planet. I suggest, Captain, that you've been lied to.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: I fail to comprehend your indignation, sir. I've simply made the  logical deduction that you are a liar.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: I'm trying, Captain.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Captain, readings of the effect indicate it centred here on this  planet, almost on this very spot.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Negative, Captain. I can no more explain the occurrence of the  second phenomenon than I can the first.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: That a single creature, a humanoid could be responsible for an  effect of such magnitude?

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Indeed.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Affirmative.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Captain, I only know for certain that the occurrence of the  phenomenon coincides exactly with the moments that Lazarus has his  alleged confrontations.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Main screen on, Lieutenant.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Source of radiation, Captain.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Because it is not there.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: What I mean, Captain, is that according to our usual scanning  procedures, there is nothing there that could be causing that effect.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Affirmative. I confess I am somewhat at a loss for words. It may  be described, though loosely and inaccurately, as a rip in our  universe.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: A kind of physical warp, Captain, in which none of our  established physical laws apply with any regularity. However, with the  dilithium crystals, I was able to localise it.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: You refer to the humanoid?

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Why does he need the crystals? For what reason?

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Unable to locate the source of radiation.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: It has simply disappeared, Captain.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: True, Captain, but more significant to me is the fact that our  ship's instruments are specifically designed to locate and identify any  object in our universe, be it energy or matter.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Correct. Which would seem to be impossible.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Perfect working condition.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Nor in our universe, Captain. It came from outside.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: The possible existence of a parallel universe has been  scientifically conceded, Captain.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Unquestionably a warp. A distortion of physical laws on an  immense scale.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Indeed. I point out that a hole in the universe or in a simple  container can either allow the contents to escape

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: There has been no evidence of a large-scale invasion.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Difficult, Captain. One moment, paranoid, the next, calm, mild,  rational. Almost as if he were two men.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Through which these two beings are somehow enabled to pass.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: The cut on his forehead. First he has it, then it's gone, then  he has it again.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Quite right. Unquestionably, there are two of him.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Jim, madness has no purpose or reason, but it may have a goal.  He must be stopped, held. Destroyed if necessary.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Two parallel universes project this. One positive, the other  negative. Or, more specifically, one matter, the other antimatter.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Precisely. Under certain conditions, when two identical  particles of matter and antimatter meet

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Annihilation, Jim. Total, complete, absolute annihilation.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Lazarus. A trick to get the crystals.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Spock to Bridge.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Lazarus.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Take these crystals to the Enterprise.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: What of Lazarus?

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: There is, of course, no escape for them, sir.

title: The  Alternative Factor
dialogue: Captain, the universe is safe.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Except for secondary systems, everything is out, sir. We're on  impulse power only.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: If Mister Scott is still with us, auxiliaries should be on  momentarily.  Are you all right,  Lieutenant?

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Mister Scott is still with us.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Captain? Casualty reports indicate only minor injuries.  Engineering reports warp engines  non-operational. Mister Scott overrode the automatic helm setting and  is holding us in orbit on impulse power.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Earth, Captain. We were on a general course in this direction  when we were pulled in by the star. Apparently the breakaway threw us  on in the same direction.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: We are too low in the atmosphere to retain this orbit, Captain.  Engineering reports we have sufficient impulse power to achieve escape  velocity.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Apparently, Captain, so are we.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Whiplash propelled us into a time warp, Captain. Backward. Exact  chronometer readings in a few moments.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Verified. Scanners report some type of craft approaching from  below us. Under cloud cover and closing.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Positive identification, Captain. Aircraft is an interceptor,  equipped with missiles, possibly armed with nuclear warheads. If he  hits us with one, he might damage us severely, perhaps beyond our  capacity to repair under current circumstances.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Captain, this type of aircraft might be too fragile to take our  tractor beam.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Aircraft is breaking up, Captain.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Neither have I.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Captain.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: We've achieved a stable orbit out of Earth's atmosphere. Our  deflectors are operative, enough to prevent our being picked up again  as a UFO. And Mister Scott wishes to speak to you about the engines.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Captain Christopher.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: We cannot return him to Earth, Captain. He already knows too  much about us and is learning more. I do not specifically refer to  Captain Christopher, but suppose an unscrupulous man were to gain  certain knowledge of man's future?  Such a man could manipulate key industries, stocks, and even nations.  and in so doing, change what must be. And if it is changed, Captain,  you and I and all that we know might not even exist.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Yes, sir.  {Captain's quarters]

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: I have investigated it, Captain. To correct the fault will  require an overhaul of the entire computer system and a minimum of  three weeks at a  Starbase.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: It also has an unfortunate tendency to giggle.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: We put in at Cygnet Fourteen for general repair and maintenance.  Cygnet Fourteen is a planet dominated by women. They seemed to feel the  ship's computer system lacked a personality. They gave it one. Female,  of course.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: I have run a computer check on all historical tapes. They show  no record of any relevant contribution by John Christopher.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Crude methods, but effective.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: I made an error in my computations.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: I find that we must return Captain Christopher to Earth after  all.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Poor choice of words on my part. I neglected, in my initial  run-through, to correlate the possible contributions by offspring. I  find, after running a crosscheck on that factor, that your son Colonel  Shaun Geoffrey Christopher headed, or will head, the first successful  Earth-Saturn probe, which is a rather significant

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: The doctor is correct. Unless we return Captain Christopher to  Earth, There will be no Colonel Shaun Geoffrey Christopher to go to  Saturn.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Acknowledging that we must return Captain  Christopher, there are several problems, prime of which is the  explanation of his return.  We tracked his plane wreckage down after our tractor beam crushed it.  It crashed in an open section of southern Nebraska.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: And Captain Christopher himself complicated the matter.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Captain, our tractor beam caught and crushed an Air Force plane.  It'll be impossible to explain this as anything other than a genuine  UFO. Possibly alien, definitely destructive.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: A theory. A reverse application of what happened to us.  Logically, it could work. Also, logically, there are a hundred  variables, any one of which could put us in a worse position than we're  in now.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Not at all. You'll simply be one of the thousands who thought he  saw a UFO.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Fifteen minutes, twenty eight seconds.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: It is a fact, Doctor, that prowling by stealth is more  time-consuming than a direct approach. In our case

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: I am.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: You may be correct, Doctor. Open communicator channel.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Beam up immediately.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: We'll know in a moment, Doctor.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: Spock here. Are you all right, Captain?

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday
dialogue: I don't believe there'll be trouble in that respect, Captain.

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday

title: Tomorrow  is Yesterday

dialogue: That is correct. I am at a loss to understand it.

dialogue: The streets are extraordinarily quiet, Captain. We've seen no  other Denevans, and the ones we stunned earlier were gone when we came  out.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: A peculiar buzzing sound. We were about to investigate it.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Incredible. Not only should it have been destroyed by our  phasers, it does not even register on my tricorder.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: It is not life as we know or understand it. Yet t is obviously  alive, it exists.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Captain, I suggest we risk taking it aboard.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: No! No!

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: No, I won't.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: I must take the ship.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Down! I must take it down.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Doctor McCoy. Captain.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: These restraints will no longer be necessary. Nor will your  sedatives, Doctor. I'll be able to return to duty. I apologise for my  weakness earlier when I tried to take control of the ship. I simply did  not understand.   What is there to understand, Mister Spock?

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: I am a Vulcan, Doctor. Pain is a thing of the mind. The mind can  be controlled.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: It is proving to be an inconvenience, but it is manageable. And  the creature, with all of its thousands of parts, even now is  pressuring me.  It  wants this ship, but I am resisting.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: I have my own will, Captain. Let me help.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: I am a Vulcan. I am a Vulcan. There is no pain.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: I was.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: I have an errand on the planet's surface. You will beam me down  to the same co-ordinates as before.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: That is an order, Mister Scott.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Until the pain was gone, Captain. It has been discontinued by  me.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: One of the creatures will have to be captured and analysed,  Captain. We did not have a clear opportunity to do so earlier when I  was attacked. Since my nervous system is already affected, as you  pointed out, Doctor, I don't believe they can do much more to me.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: I am in complete control of myself, Doctor. The fact that I am  here proves that I do not belong in bed.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Thank you, Captain.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Come in, gentlemen. I believe you'll find this interesting.   Doctor, your medical skill and curiosity are quite  admirable, but I assure you I'm all right.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Unimportant at the moment, Doctor. Please observe. Interesting,  gentlemen. A one-celled creature resembling, more than anything else, a  huge, individual brain cell.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Do you understand what I'm suggesting, Captain?

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: And although it is not physically connected to the other cells,  it is nevertheless part of the whole creature, guided by the whole,  drawing its strength from the whole, which probably accounts for its  unusual resistance to our phaser weapons.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: From a place where our physical laws do not apply. We may  therefore find it difficult to destroy, Captain.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Yes, sir.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: I regret I see no other choice for you, Captain. We already know  this thing has destroyed three civilisations. Perhaps more.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Including myself, Doctor, and Captain Kirk's young nephew.  Understandably upsetting, but once it spreads past here, there are  dozens of colonies beyond and billions of people.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: I therefore request permission to beam down to the planet's  surface. I also suggest that your nephew accompany me.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Captain, I do not make this request lightly. I do not know how  much longer I can hold out against the pain. But I do know what the boy  will go through should he regain consciousness.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: It exists physically. It occupies space. It has mass, therefore  gravity. It converts matter to energy.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: A possibility.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Yes. In essence, it can be done. A string of satellites around  the planet with burning tri-magnesite and trevium.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Of course. The light of the sun at the proximity where the  Denevan declared himself free was one million candles per square inch.  If this works, the satellites we orbit will produce light of such  intensity that even someone in a closed, darkened area will be affected  by it.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Captain, you'll need a host for the next step in the test to  determine whether the creature can be driven from the body. I am the  logical choice.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: There'll be none on the planet's surface, Doctor.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: The creature within me is gone. I am free of it and the pain.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: And I'm also quite blind. An equitable trade, Doctor. Thank you.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Interesting. Just as dogs are sensitive to certain sounds which  humans cannot hear, these creatures evidently are sensitive to light  which we cannot see.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Doctor it was my selection as well. It is done.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: An hereditary trait, Captain. The brightness of the Vulcan sun  has caused the development of an inner eyelid, which acts as a shield  against high-intensity light. Totally instinctive, Doctor. We tend to  ignore it, as you ignore your own appendix.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Quite the contrary, Captain. I had a very strong reaction. My  first sight was the face of Doctor McCoy bending over me.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: My pleasure, Captain.

title: Operation:  Annihilate!
dialogue: Why, thank you, Doctor McCoy.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: They may have nothing to report. Our sensors indicate no life  forms except our landing party.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: No cloud formations, no bodies of water, no changes in surface  temperature. Under these conditions, fog is highly unlikely, Captain.  According to our transporter co-ordinates this is the exact location  from which Jackson was beamed up to the ship.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: No indications of. A moment, Captain. Picking up life form  readings. Twenty four degrees mark seven. Range one thirty seven point  one six metres. Multiple readings, Captain.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: No change, Captain.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Very bad poetry, Captain.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: What we've just seen is not real.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: However, on azimuth twenty four, at just over one hundred  metres, there are definitely life forms. Erratic, confused, but  definitely registering.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: This is the source of the life form readings, Captain. They're  inside, somewhere.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: I would say not, Captain. There's no indication of anything that  would cause such interference.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Nor do our sensors register the life forms inside.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Trick or treat, Captain?

title: Catspaw
dialogue: That would seem to be in order.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: The readings would so indicate.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Yes. I am undamaged, Captain.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: I do not know, Captain, but these things do exist. They are  real.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: As if someone knew what it was that terrifies man most on an  instinctive level.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Neither did Jackson just before he collapsed.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Mapping expeditions have charted this solar system before. There  never have been any life forms on Pyris Seven.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: There are ancient Earth legends about wizards and their  familiars.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Demons in animal forms sent by Satan to serve the wizard.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: I do not create the legend, Captain. I merely report it.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Ingenious.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Mind probing? Hypnosis?

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Telepathy?

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Not entirely, no. Telepathy doesn't imply control and I assure  you that I have full control over your friends.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Twenty two minutes, seventeen seconds.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: I'm sure we'll find out shortly. Jim, all of these things that  we've seen. To an Earthman like yourself, they must seem quite  familiar.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Precisely. I refer you to the psychological theory of the racial  subconscious. The universal myths, symbols.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: And dungeons and castles and black cats. They all belong to the  twilight world of consciousness.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: And they missed. They reached basically only the subconscious.  Korob seemed  puzzled by your reaction to the environment he'd provided.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: And not to have a knowledge of our scientific methods is most  unlikely for any life form we've met in this galaxy.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Evidently something totally alien in all respects.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: I, too, am at a loss at this time to suggest a course of action.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: You came in a ship?

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Racial memories. The cat is the most ruthless, most terrifying  of animals, as far back as the sabre-toothed tiger.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Ready when you are, Captain.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Quickly, Captain.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Captain, a bit more alacrity, if you please.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Captain.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Jim!

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Fortuitous, Captain. And now that we have them all together?   A most unpleasant situation, Captain. If only your  phaser had some power.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Don't let her touch the wand, Captain.

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Jim!

title: Catspaw
dialogue: Fascinating. A life form totally alien to our galaxy. If we  could preserve and study this

title: Metamorphosis

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Captain.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Will you check your automatic scanner, please?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Nor have I.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Heading directly toward us at warp speed.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Vaguely like a cloud of ionised hydrogen, but with strong  erratic electrical impulses.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Helm does not answer, Captain.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Cut, Captain.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Now on course nine eight mark one two, heading directly toward  Gamma Canaris region.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Gravity is similar to Earth. Most unusual in view of its size.  The bulk of the body seems to be iron and nickel. More than an  asteroid. Like a small planetoid, I should say. Possibly a remnant of a  planet breakup. Totally suitable for human life.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Most unusual. Unlikely. In fact, Captain, I would say quite  impossible.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Precisely.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Obviously.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: The ionised cloud.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Correct.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Which seems to be on the surface of this body at the moment.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: You say we'll be unable to get the ship to function again?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: You don't mind if we continue to try?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: You built this, Mister Cochrane?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Not bad.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Captain, Doctor.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: We imagined nothing, Mister Cochrane. There was an entity out  there and I suspect it was the same entity which brought us here.  Please explain.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: You were injured?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: I prefer to reserve judgment on that part of your story, sir.  Meanwhile, would you please explain exactly what this Companion of  yours is?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: The name of Zefram Cochrane is revered throughout the known  galaxy. Planets were named after him. Great universities, cities.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: True, his body was never found.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: If so, you wear your age very well.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Captain. These instruments, they date from the time indicated.  From your ship, Mister Cochrane?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: You ask me to find a weapon. Do you intend to destroy it?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Quite clear, Captain.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Yes. Quite all right, Doctor. A most fascinating thing happened.  Apparently, the Companion imparted to me a rather quaint, old-fashioned  electric shock of respectable voltage.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Evidently. Unquestionably, a large part of its substance is  simple electricity.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Quite correct, Doctor.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Put this in the proximity of the Companion, throw this switch,  and it will scramble every electrical impulse the creature can produce.  It cannot fail.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: We may simply render it powerless.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: There is some risk, Captain. We do not know the extent of its  powers.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: All right.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Yes, Captain?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: The translator is for use with more congruent life forms.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: It is possible. If I could widen its pattern of reception

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Then it translates its findings into English.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Quite ready, Captain.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Yes. The matter of gender could change the entire situation.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Then it is not a zookeeper.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: This is a marvellous opportunity to add to our knowledge. Ask it  about its nature, its history.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: A chance like this may never come again. It could tell us so  much.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Her attitude when she approaches you is profoundly different  than when she contacts us. Her appearance is soft, gentle. Her voice is  melodic, pleasing. I do not totally understand the emotion, but it  obviously exists. The Companion loves you.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Your highly emotional reaction is most illogical. Your  relationship with the Companion has for one hundred and fifty years  been emotionally satisfying,  eminently practical, and totally harmless. It may indeed have been  quite beneficial.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Fascinating. A totally parochial attitude.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: But she or it is inhuman, Captain. You cannot expect her to  react like a human.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Companion, you do not have the power to create life.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Commissioner Hedford was dying.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Then you are both here, in the one body?

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: Not coming from a human being. You are, after all, essentially  irrational.

title: Metamorphosis
dialogue: But you will age, both of you. There will be no immortality.  You'll both grow old here and finally die.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Ordinarily, under these circumstances, I would recommend a  large, well-armed landing party.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: He also mentioned that they can be highly dangerous.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Inefficient, however. Emotion, Captain.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: It would appear, Captain, that he finds you a disappointment.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Our check-in signal is one hour, twelve minutes overdue. Since  no reconnaissance party has appeared, and since Mister Scott is notably  efficient in such matters

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: That would seem a logical conclusion.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Yes, Captain, an excellent idea.

title: Friday's  Child

dialogue: Captain, I didn't say that exactly.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: There would seem to be little weapon potential at hand.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Fortunately, this bark has suitable tensile cohesion.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: I believe I said that.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: I would rather, I would rather not. Thank you.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: That should prove very interesting.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: The child?

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Virtue is a relative term, Doctor. She'll head straight to the  warriors.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Here, Captain. Over here, Captain.  Spock to Enterprise.

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Revenge, Captain?

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Oochy-woochy coochy-coo, Captain?

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: Well, at any rate, this should prove interesting.

title: Friday's  Child

title: Friday's  Child

dialogue: The child's regent?

dialogue: The child was named Leonard James Akaar?

title: Friday's  Child
dialogue: I think you're both going to be insufferably pleased with  yourselves for at least a month, sir.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Pollux Four. Class M type planet, oxygen and nitrogen  atmosphere. Sensors indicate no life forms. Approximate age four  billion years. Judged no reason for contact. In all respects, quite  ordinary, Captain.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Momentarily.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Negative, Captain. Not living tissue.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Not a projection, sir. A field of energy.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: The ship is almost completely encircled by the field. It  resembles a conventional force field but on unusual wavelengths.  Despite its appearance, that of a human appendage, it is definitely not  living tissue. It is energy.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Captain, a most curious development on scanner five seven.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Screen on, Captain.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Verbose, isn't he?

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Insults are effective only where emotion is present.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Try to break through it, Lieutenant.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Very efficient. Mister Sulu, rig all transmission circuits for  maximum power generation. Compute for reversal of polarity of the field  around the ship.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Lieutenant Kyle, I want a complete sensor scan of the planet.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Locate all the lifeforms. I want to know what's going on down  there.

dialogue: Ready to reverse polarity, Mister Sulu?

dialogue: Activate all units.

dialogue: Good. Do so. Sensor report, Mister Kyle.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: And Apollo?

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Origin?

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: I would suggest, Mister Sulu, if you cannot find out where the  power source is, you should find out where it is not. A simple process  of elimination.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Progress report.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Speed is essential, Lieutenant.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Progress, Mister Sulu?

dialogue: Mister Kyle.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: To shoot through. It might also relieve Lieutenant Uhura's  communications problem. Take these equations to the nuclear electronics  lab. I want them to work on the problem of negating the force field in  selected areas. That might be done by generating a strong pinpoint  charge of M-rays on some of these selected wave lengths and tying them  in with the combined output of all our engines.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Spock here, Captain.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?
dialogue: Captain. I would recommend a discreet  distance.

title: Who  Mourns For Adonais?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Captain, I should like to request a leave of absence on my home  planet. On our present course you can divert to Vulcan with a loss of  but two point eight light days.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: I have made my request, Captain. All I require from you is that  you answer it. Yes or no.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: It is undignified for a woman to play servant to a man who is  not hers.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: You have my request, Captain. Will you grant it or not?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Captain, surely I have enough leave time accumulated.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: No. Nothing of that nature, Captain.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: No! I must. I wish to take my leave on Vulcan.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: I need rest. I'm asking you to accept that answer.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Thank you, Captain.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: No.  We're not.   Captain's log, stardate 3372.7. On course, on  schedule, bound for Altair Six via Vulcan. First Officer Spock seems to  be under stress. He has requested and been granted shore leave. Ship  surgeon McCoy has him under medical surveillance.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: I quite understand, Captain.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Changed the course?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: No. No, by no means, Captain. It is quite possible.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Captain, I accept on your word that I did it, but I do not know  why, nor do I remember doing it. Captain, lock me away. I do not wish  to be seen. I cannot. No Vulcan could explain further.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Ask me no further questions. I will not answer.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Sickbay?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: My orders were to report to Sickbay, Doctor. I have done so. And  now I'll go to my quarters.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Examine me, for all the good it'll do either of us.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Come.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: It is a thing no out-worlder may know except those very few who  have been involved. A Vulcan understands, but even we do not speak of  it among ourselves. It is a deeply personal thing. Can you see that,  Captain, and understand?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Captain, there are some things which transcend even the  discipline of the service.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: It has to do with biology.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Biology.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Vulcan biology.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: The birds and the bees are not Vulcans, Captain. If they were,  if any creature as proudly logical as us were to have their logic  ripped from them as this time does to us. How do Vulcans choose their  mates? Haven't you wondered?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: No. No. It is not. We shield it with ritual and customs shrouded  in antiquity. You humans have no conception. It strips our minds from  us. It brings a madness which rips away our veneer of civilisation. It  is the pon farr. The time of mating. There are precedents in nature,  Captain. The giant eelbirds of Regulus Five, once each eleven years  they must return to the caverns where they hatched.  On your Earth, the salmon. They must return to that one stream where  they were born, to spawn or die in trying.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: No. Nor am I a man. I'm a Vulcan. I'd hoped I would be spared  this, but the ancient drives are too strong. Eventually, they catch up  with us, and we are driven by forces we cannot control to return home  and take a wife. Or die.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Let me alone. Let me alone!

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Miss Chapel.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: I had a most startling dream. You were trying to tell me  something, but I couldn't hear you. It would be illogical for us to  protest against our natures. Don't you think?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Your face is wet.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Vulcan. Miss Chapel.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Yes, I know, Christine. Would you make me some of that plomeek  soup?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: It is obvious that you have surmised my problem, Doctor. My  compliments on your insight. Captain, there is a thing that happens to  Vulcans at this time. Almost an insanity, which you would no doubt find  distasteful.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Then would you beam down to the planet's surface and stand with  me? There is a brief ceremony.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: It is my right. By tradition, the male is accompanied by his  closest friends.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: I also request McCoy accompany me.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: This is Spock.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: T'Pring, parted from me and never parted, never and always  touching and touched. We meet at the appointed place.   T'PRING : Spock, parted from me and never parted, never  and always touching and touched. I await you.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: She is T'Pring. My wife.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: This is the land of my family. It has been held by us for more  than two thousand  Earth years. This is our place of Koon-ut-kal-if-fee,

title: Amok Time
dialogue: The marriage party approaches. I hear them.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: By our parents' arrangement. A ceremony while we were but seven  years of age. Less than a marriage but more than a betrothal.  One touches the other in order to feel each other's thoughts. In this  way our minds were locked together, so that at the proper time, we  would both be drawn to Koon-ut-kal-if-fee.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: They are not outworlders. They are my friends. I am permitted  this.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: This is Kirk.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: With my life, T'Pau.   T'PAU: What they are about to see comes down from the time of the  beginning, without change. This is the Vulcan heart. This is the Vulcan  soul. This is our way. Kah-if-farr.      T'PRING: Kal-if-fee!

title: Amok Time
dialogue: T'Pau.   T'PAU: Thee speaks?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: My friend does not understand.   T'PAU: The choice has been made, Spock. It is up to him now.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: He does not know. I will do what I must, T'Pau, but not with  him! His blood does not burn. He is my friend!   T'PAU: It is said thy Vulcan blood is thin. Are thee Vulcan or are thee  human?

title: Amok Time
dialogue: I burn, T'Pau. My eyes are flame. My heart is flame. Thee has  the power, T'Pau. In the name of my fathers, forbid. Forbid! T'Pau. I  plead with thee! I beg!   T'PAU: Thee has prided thyself on thy Vulcan heritage. It is decided.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Yes. I'll follow you up in a few minutes. You will instruct  Mister Chekov to plot a course for the nearest Starbase where I must  surrender myself to the authorities.  T'Pring. Explain.   T'PRING: Specify.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Why the challenge, and why you chose my captain as your  champion.   T'PRING: Stonn wanted me, I wanted him.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: I see no logic in preferring Stonn over me.   T'PRING: You have become much known among our people, Spock. Almost a  legend. And as the years went by, I came to know that I did not want to  be the consort of a legend. But by the laws of our people, I could only  divorce you by the kal-if-fee. There was also Stonn, who wanted very  much to be my  consort, and I wanted him. If your Captain were victor, he would not  want me, and so I would have Stonn. If you were victor you would free  me because I had dared to challenge, and again I would have Stonn. But  if you did not free me, it would be the same. For you would be gone,  and I would have your name and your property, and Stonn would still be  there.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Logical. Flawlessly logical.   T'PRING: I am honoured.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Stonn. She is yours. After a time, you may find that having is  not so pleasing a thing after all as wanting. It is not logical, but it  is often true. Spock here. Stand by to beam up. Live long, T'Pau, and  prosper.   T'PAU: Live long and prosper, Spock.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: I shall do neither. I have killed my captain and my friend.  Energize.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Doctor, I shall be resigning my commission  immediately, of course.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: So I would appreciate your making the final arrangements.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Doctor, please, let me finish. There can be no excuse for the  crime of which I'm guilty. I intend to offer no defence. Furthermore, I  shall order Mister Scott to take immediate command of this vessel.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Captain! Jim!

title: Amok Time
dialogue: I'm pleased to see you, Captain. You seem uninjured. I am at  something of a loss to understand it, however.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Indeed.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Ah, yes, the girl. Most interesting. It must have been the  combat. When I thought I had killed the captain, I found I had lost all  interest in T'Pring. The madness was gone.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Merely my quite logical relief that Starfleet had not lost a  highly proficient captain.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Thank you, Captain.

title: Amok Time
dialogue: Thank you, Doctor.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Captain, sensors show this entire solar system has been  destroyed. Nothing left but rubble and asteroids.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Nonetheless, Captain, sensors show nothing but debris where we  charted seven planets last year.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Captain, the two inner most planets of this system appear to be  intact.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: I have it on the sensors, Captain. By configuration, a starship  stopped in space. She appears to be drifting.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Sensors not recording normal energy output.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: She may have been wrecked by whatever destroyed these solar  systems.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: All power plants dead, reserve energy banks operative at a very  low power level.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Also operative at a low power level. The entire Bridge is  damaged and uninhabitable. The rest of the ship seems able to sustain  life.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Normal, but subspace interference makes readings difficult.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Acknowledged.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Improbable, Captain. The surface temperature of the inner planet  is that of molten lead. The other has an atmosphere poisonous to human  life.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Unable to raise Starfleet Command due to  heavy subspace interference.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: She was attacked by what appears to be  essentially a robot, an automated weapon of immense size and power. Its  apparent function is to smash planets to rubble and then digest the  debris for fuel. It is, therefore, self-sustaining  as long as there are planetary bodies for it to feed on.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Unknown, Captain. However, Mister Sulu has  computed the path of the machine, using the destroyed solar systems as  a base course.  Projecting back on our star charts, we find that it came from outside,  from another galaxy.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: If it follows its present path, it will go through the most  densely populated section of our galaxy.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: It came up on us fast, Captain, but we seem  able to maintain our distance.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: It looks very much like Commodore Decker's planet killer. And it  is pursuing us.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: We are more manoeuvrable, but it is gaining on us. Sensors  indicate some kind of total conversion drive.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: I would say none, Captain. The energy  generated by our power nacelles seems to attracts it. I doubt we could  manoeuvre close enough without drawing a direct attack upon ourselves.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Closing, Captain.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Evasive action, Mister Sulu.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Damage report, all stations.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Affect repairs. Captain Kirk, come in please.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Captain, we've been attacked. The transporter is damaged. We're  taking evasive action.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: We have outrun it, Doctor.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Impulse and warp engines operative, transporter and  communications under repair. Random chance seems to have operated in  our favour.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: I believe I said that, Doctor.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Evidently programmed to ignore anything as small as a ship  beyond a certain radius. We'll maintain a discreet distance and circle  back to pick up the Captain.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: I am aware of the Rigel system's population, Commodore, but we  are only one ship. Our deflector shields are strained, our subspace  transmitter is useless. Logically, our primary duty is to survive in  order to warn Starfleet Command.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Mister Sulu, you will lay in an evasive course back to the  Constellation.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: You will carry out my last order, Mister Sulu.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: You have the right to do so, but I would advise against it.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: You tried to destroy it once before, Commodore. The result was a  wrecked ship and a dead crew.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Sensors show the object's hull is solid neutronium. A single  ship cannot combat it.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Unfortunately, Starfleet Order 104, Section B, leaves me no  alternative. Paragraph 1A clearly states

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: If you can certify Commodore Decker medically or psychologically  unfit for command, I can relieve him under Section C.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: You'll also be asked to produce your medical records to prove  it.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Then your statement would not be considered valid.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Deflector shields at full power. They can't take much more of  this.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Deflectors holding, but weakening. We must retreat, Commodore.  The energy drain

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Commodore, I urgently recommend immediate withdrawal.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Sir, deflector shields are gone.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: It has ceased fire. We're being held in a tractor beam. We're  being pulled inside, Commodore. You must veer off.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: We have lost warp power. If we don't break the tractor beam  within sixty seconds, we never will.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: That, sir, is illogical. It is suicide. Attempted suicide would  be proof that you are psychologically unfit for command. If you don't  veer off, I shall relieve you on that basis.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Emergency impulse power.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: We need more power.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: It's closing fast on the Constellation.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Commodore, I suggest

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: This machine seems to have a programmed defensive sphere. Any  energy source entering that field is subject to attack.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Warp drive and deflectors will be out for a solar day. Repairs  proceeding on transporter and communications.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: We can maintain this speed for only seven hours before we  exhaust our fuel, but it can refuel itself indefinitely.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Illogical. We cannot destroy it. Therefore, we cannot save  Rigel. We must transport the Captain and the others from the  Constellation  and escape this thing's subspace interference in order to warn  Starfleet Command.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Can you raise Starfleet?

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: On audio, Lieutenant.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Commodore.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Warp drive out. Deflector shields down. Transporter under  repair. We are on emergency impulse power.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: At our present rate of consumption, we'll  exhaust our impulse power long before then.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Commodore Decker, you are relieved of  command.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: You may file a formal protest with Starfleet Command, assuming  we survive to reach a Starbase. But you are relieved. Commodore. I do  not wish to place you under arrest.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Vulcans never bluff.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Captain, I have assumed command.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: One moment, sir. Commodore. I believe you are scheduled for  medical examination. Mister Montgomery.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: You will accompany the commodore to Sickbay.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Mister Sulu, change course. Seven zero mark two one.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Captain, we are taking an evasive course back to you. We will  try to stay ahead of the object until we can transport you aboard.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Shut them, Mister Sulu.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Whoever it is, Captain, has no  authorisation. Lieutenant, raise the shuttlecraft.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Commodore, I must insist that you return to  the ship.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: You cannot succeed, Commodore. Your only  logical alternative is to return to the ship.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: He's gone. Constellation, come in, please.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Sir, may I offer my condolences on the death  of your friend. It is most regrettable.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: The drop in power is definite, Captain but negligible. The  object is still pursing us, thereby causing us to drain our power  reserve at a much greater rate.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Transporter operational, Captain. Shall we beam you aboard?

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: There's little to be gained by staying aboard the Constellation.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Acknowledged. Transporter Room. Beam damage  control party aboard.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: No, sir. Ninety seven point eight three five  megatons.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Negative, Captain. Its hull is pure  neutronium. There is no known way of blasting through it.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Insufficient data. I shall try to take  further sensor readings.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: The object's neutronium hull makes sensor  readings of the inner mechanism impossible.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Captain, you're getting dangerously close to  the planet killer.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Jim, you'll be killed, just like Decker.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Your chances of survival are not promising.  We don't even know if the explosion will be powerful enough.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Thirty seconds is very slim timing.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Transporter is out, Captain. You'll have to  stand by.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Captain, transporter operational, but just barely.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Transporter, stand by.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Energise.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Mister Scott, twenty seconds to detonation.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Mister Scott

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Energy output zero. Radiation level normal.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Welcome aboard, Captain. Sensors show all energy sources  deactivated. It's quite dead.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Indeed, Captain. I presume your log will show that Commodore  Decker died in the line of duty.

title: The  Doomsday Machine
dialogue: Appropriate, Captain. However, I can't help wondering if there  are any more of those weapons wandering around the universe.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Enterprise. Spock here.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Acknowledged. Co-ordinates received.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Concerning the situation you related to us.  In my opinion, the Argelian empathic contact is an interesting  phenomenon, but the technique is not sound enough to risk a man's life.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Simply that we beam Mister Scott on board  the Enterprise and employ our computers to learn the truth.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Quite clear, Captain.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Anger is a relative state, sir. Were you angry enough to do  violence?

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Sensitivity of certain Argelian women is a documented fact,  Captain.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: To us, perhaps, but to the computer?

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Computer, linguistic bank. Definition of following word. Redjac.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: There is no such word in the linguistics bank?

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Scan all other banks.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Define.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Humans and humanoids make up only a small percentage of the life  forms we know of. There are entities possessed of extremely long life  spans, virtually immortal.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: In the strict scientific sense, Doctor, we all feed on death.  Even vegetarians.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Which would tend to support the proposition that the murderer  was not human. Deriving sustenance from emotion is not unknown in the  galaxy, and fear is among the strongest and most violent of the  emotions.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Computer, digest log recordings for past five solar minutes.  Correlate hypotheses. Compare with life forms register. Question. Could  such an entity within discussed limits exist in this galaxy?

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Computer, extrapolate most likely composition of such entity.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Working. To meet with specified requirements, entity would exist  without form in conventional sense. Most probable mass of energy  of highly cohesive electromagnetic field.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: I point out that Jack the Ripper slew at will in the heart of  the most populous city of old Earth  and was never identified.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: I suggest the possibility of a hypnotic screen, which blinds all  but the victim to the presence of the killer.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: And I suspect preys on women because women are more easily and  more deeply terrified, generating more sheer horror than the male of  the species.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Captain, those places are aligned directly between Argelius and  Earth.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: I can appreciate your position, sir. You are in charge of civil  disturbances locally. If you are the entity for which we search, what  better position from which to kill with impunity?

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: An entity which feeds on fear and terror would find a perfect  hunting ground on Argelius, a planet without violence, where the  inhabitants are as peaceful as sheep. The entity would be as a hungry  wolf in that fold.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Computer. Report on analysis of Exhibit A.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Specify. Point of origin.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: The computer will not respond to these controls. The entity is  unquestionably controlling it.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: It's no use, Captain. The bypass circuits are blocked.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Indeed, it will try, but not immediately. We know it feeds on  fear and terror. There are nearly four hundred and forty humans aboard  this ship. Surely it will try to breed fear and terror before it kills.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Yes we do, Captain, but with the entity in control

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Indeed. If we could focus the attention of the computer on one  of them.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Apparently our friends learned very quickly.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Freefall!

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: We don't have much time, Captain.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Normal environmental levels have been restored, Captain, but it  will not last long. A few hours at best.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Proceeding, Captain, but I will need some time.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: It is attempting to generate terror, Captain.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Ready.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Computer, this is a Class A compulsory directive. Compute to the  last digit the value of pi.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: As we know, the value of pi is a transcendental figure without  resolution. The computer banks will work on this problem to the  exclusion of all else until we order it to stop.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: There is resistance, Captain, but the directive is succeeding.  Bank after bank is turning to the problem.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Complete computer control, Captain. The entity has fled.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Possibly, Doctor. Its consciousness may continue for some time,  consisting of billions of separate bits of energy, floating forever in  space, powerless.

title: Wolf  In The Fold
dialogue: Captain, since you came to Argelius to rest, I suggest you take  advantage of the opportunity.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Captain. They will not answer. The long-range sensor sweep of  this system reveals no sign of life.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: I register no life readings at all, sir.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: We would have known in advance of any system-wide catastrophe,  and in the event of an interplanetary war, there would be considerable  radioactive residue. Our instruments show only normal background  radiation.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Unknown, sir. Sensor readings would have revealed the presence  of any disease organisms. They do not. In addition, we received the  routine report from this system only a week ago. Even the Symbalene  blood burn does not act that swiftly.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: An extremely powerful bolt of energy, Captain.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Temporarily, Captain. Our shields absorbed energy equivalent to  ninety of our photon torpedoes.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: I may add, the energy used repulsing this first attack reduced  our shielding power twenty percent.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: We can resist three more such attacks. The fourth will shatter  our shields completely.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Approximately warp fifteen, Captain.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Unknown, Captain. Nothing within sensor range.  Something now, Captain. Very small. Bearing one two three  degrees, mark one eight. Range ninety thousand kilometres.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: No, sir. Holding steady.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: No effect. Target absorbed full energy of our torpedo.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: They are in good working order, Captain.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Captain, shields are down. We cannot survive another hit.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Computing now, Captain. Weight, five hundred kilograms. Shape,  roughly cylindrical. Length, a fraction over one metre.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Intelligence does not necessarily require bulk, Mister Scott.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Captain, this message is a sort of binary. Extremely  sophisticated, compressed, carrying several channels at once.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: No clue as yet, Captain. A moment. Transmission speed has  stepped down. Much slower. Seems to be a single binary.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: It would seem so, Captain.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: It's a formula, Captain. They're sending us a mathematical  message and requesting language equivalence. They're trying to  communicate.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Cut power, Lieutenant. Overloaded and burned out.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Nomad?

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Negative, Captain. It has a protective screen. I cannot get  through.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: A reasonable course.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: It is reacting much like a highly sophisticated computer.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: An opinion is a belief, a view, a judgment.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Yes. It was reported destroyed. There were no more in the  series. But if this is that probe

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Chart 14A, sir?

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: I believe the history computer can answer that question. I'll  have the readout in a moment.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: The usage is correct. The creator was simply testing your memory  banks.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: I've correlated all the available information on the Nomad  probe, and I'm convinced that this object is indeed that probe.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: True.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Presumed destroyed by a meteor collision. I submit that it was  badly damaged and somehow managed to repair itself.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: This is the creator of Nomad, perhaps the  most brilliant though erratic scientist of his time. His dream was to  build a perfect thinking machine, capable of independent logic. You  recall his name.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Yes. Similar. Captain, I believe that Nomad thinks you are  Roykirk. That may well be why the attack was broken off. It responded  to your name as well as its damaged memory banks permitted.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Essentially it is, Doctor. I believe that more happened to it  than just damage in the meteor collision. It mentioned the other. The  unanswered question is, the other what?   Nomad was a thinking machine, the best that could be engineered. It was  a prototype.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Precisely, Doctor. And somehow that programming has been  changed. It would seem that Nomad is now seeking out perfect  life-forms, perfection being measured by its own relentless logic.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Captain, Mister Singh reports that Nomad is no longer in the  auxiliary control room.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: That unit is a woman.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Nomad, I have arranged the tapes for flash feed at the top speed  of the computer. Please do not draw the information faster than the  machine's capacity.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Well, Doctor?

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Captain, if that is correct, if there has been no brain damage  but only knowledge erased, she could be re-educated.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Does the creator wish Nomad to wait elsewhere?

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Doctor, I interrupted you because Nomad would not have  understood your anger. It has great technical skill, but its reaction  to emotion is unpredictable. It almost qualifies as a life-form.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: The study of it would be of great use, Captain.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Yes, sir.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: An almost human stubbornness, Captain. I have been unable to  convince Nomad to lower its screens for analysis. Without its  co-operation, I can do nothing.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Thank you.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: It is not sufficient, Captain. I get certain  references to the accident, the other, but nothing clear. There are  areas I simply cannot scan.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Captain, I suggest the Vulcan mind probe.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: It seems the only way.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: There is a risk, but I have formed a partial hypothesis. I must  check it out.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: I. Am. Nomad. I am performing my function. Deep emptiness, It  approaches. Collision. Damage. Blackness. I. Am. The other. I am Tan  Ru, Tan Ru. Nomad. Tan Ru. Error. Flaw. Imperfection. Must sterilise.  Rebirth. We are complete. Much power. Gun ta. Noo. Icka. Tan Ru. The  creator instructs. Search out. Identify. Sterilise imperfections. We  are Nomad.  We are Nomad. We are complete. We are instructed. Our purpose is clear.  Sterilise imperfections.  Sterilise imperfections.  Nomad. Sterilise. Sterilise. Nomad, sterilise,

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Fascinating, Captain. The knowledge. The depth.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: It was, it was damaged in deep space. Undoubtedly, the meteor  collision. Its memory banks were destroyed, or most of them. It  wandered without purpose, and then it met the other. The other was an  alien probe of great power. Somehow they merged,  repaired each other, became one.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Not the Nomad we lost from Earth. It took from the other a new  directive to replace its own. The other was originally programmed to  secure and sterilise soil samples from other planets, probably as a  prelude to colonisation.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: I beg your pardon?

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: And that is the only thing that has saved us until now.   Yes.

title: The  Changeling
dialogue: Captain. I've examined the brig. The forcefield door on the  security cell is damaged and the guards have vanished. I must assume  they are dead.

title: The  Changeling

dialogue: Nevertheless Captain, the Klingons would not enjoy seeing us  successfully develop Sherman's Planet.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: But not totally unexpected.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: A most curious creature, Captain. Its  trilling seems to have a tranquillising effect on the human nervous  system. Fortunately, of course, I am immune to its effect.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: Captain, may I ask where you'll be?

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: There's something disquieting about these creatures.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: Don't be insulting, Doctor. They remind me of the lilies of the  field. They toil not, neither do they spin. But they seem to eat a  great deal. I see no practical use for them.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: So would an ermine violin, but I see no advantage in having one.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: Doctor, I am well aware of human characteristics. I am  frequently inundated by them, but I've trained myself to put up with  practically anything.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: What is that, Doctor?

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: Doctor?

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: They do have one redeeming characteristic.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: They do not talk too much. If you'll excuse me, sir.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: Captain, I am forced to agree with the doctor. I've been running  computations on their rate of reproduction. The figures are taking an  alarming direction. They're consuming our supplies and returning  nothing.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: Surely you must have realised what would happen if you removed  the tribbles from their predator-filled environment into an environment  where their natural multiplicative proclivities would have no  restraining factors.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: By removing the tribbles from their natural habitat, you have,  so to speak, removed the cork from the bottle and allowed the genie to  escape.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: He simply could not believe his ears.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles
dialogue: We have already checked on the background of Mister Cyrano  Jones. He is a licensed asteroid locator and prospector. He's never  broken the law, at least not severely. For the past seven years, with  his one-man spaceship, he's obtained a marginal living by engaging in  the buying and selling of rare merchandise, including, unfortunately,  tribbles.

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles

title: The  Trouble With Tribbles

title: Bread  And Circuses

dialogue: SS Beagle. Small class four stardrive vessel. Crew of forty  seven, commanded by. Jim, I believe you knew him. Captain R M Merik.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Different in shape only, Captain. The proportion of land to  water is exactly as on your Earth. Density five point five, diameter  seven nine one seven at the equator, atmosphere seventy eight percent  nitrogen, twenty one percent oxygen. Again, exactly like Earth.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: I also picked up indications of large cities.

title: Bread  And Circuses

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: But hardly more practical, captain. Close to the city we  located, but not populated. We should not be observed.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Fascinating. This atmosphere is remarkably similar to your  twentieth century. Moderately industrialised pollution containing  substantial amounts of carbon monoxide and partially consumed  hydrocarbons.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Yes, I believe that was the term. I had no idea you were that  much of a historian, Doctor.

title: Bread  And Circuses

dialogue: I fail to see the humour in that situation, Doctor.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Complete Earth parallel. The language here is English.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: There would seem to be evidence to that effect.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: I call them ears.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Never. Colloquial twentieth-century English. An amazing  parallel.

dialogue: Sir, we came here looking for some friends, forty seven of them  who were stranded here some six years ago. They wore clothing similar  to ours. Have you heard of such men?

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Captain, I thought you might find this  interesting.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Fascinating.

dialogue: Captain, a logical question, if I may. Septimus, how many years  ago did Merikus become your first citizen?

dialogue: Curious, Captain, the similarity in names. Were you told why  Merik was dropped from the Space Academy?

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Why, Doctor?

dialogue: Even more fascinating. Slavery evolving into an institution with  guaranteed medical payments, old-age pensions.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Interesting, and given a conservative empire, quite  understandable.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: I said I understood it, Doctor. I find the checks and balances  of this civilisation quite illuminating.

title: Bread  And Circuses

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Situations quite familiar to the six million who died in your  first world war, the eleven million who died in your second, the thirty  seven million who died in your third. Shall I go on?

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: Quite correct.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: I tell you I'm well able to defeat you.

title: Bread  And Circuses
dialogue: I do not want to injure you.

dialogue: Need any help, Doctor?

dialogue: Yes, that's quite true.

title: Bread  And Circuses

dialogue: Really, Doctor?

dialogue: What did they do to you?

title: Journey  to Babel

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Captain, Ambassador Sarek and his wife are my parents.   Captain's log, Stardate 3842.3. We have departed  Vulcan for the neutral planetoid code-named Babel. Since it is in our  sector, the Enterprise has been assigned to transport ambassadors of  Federation planets to this vitally important council. The issues of the  council are politically complex, the passengers explosive.

dialogue: The situation between my father and myself has not changed.

dialogue: Guess, Captain? I shall need more data for my estimate.

dialogue: Vessel changing course, heading toward us at  high warp speed.

dialogue: Interesting. They were travelling at approximately warp ten.

dialogue: Indeed, Captain? Interesting.

dialogue: Vulcans do not approve of violence.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: No, Captain. I'm merely saying it would be illogical to kill  without reason.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: If there were a reason, my father is quite capable of killing.  Logically and efficiently.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Mother. If only on circumstantial evidence, he is a logical  suspect.

dialogue: Yes, Captain. I get sensor readings of tri-tritanium from the  alien ship's hull.

dialogue: Yes, it could adversely affect our mission.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Worry is a human emotion, Captain. I accept what has happened.  The ship's hull seems to have a high density level  or is cloaked against sensor probes. It is manned, but sensors cannot  make out specifics.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: I think it unlikely it is one of theirs.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Possibly, Captain. But I cannot decode this transmission.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: It is in no known code. There's no detectable pattern. No  standard references apply.

dialogue: Only negative. It fits none of our computer records, and it is  alien.

dialogue: Doctor, do you propose surgery for the heart defect?
