dialogue: I suggest that a cryogenic open-heart procedure would be the  logical approach.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: My blood is T-negative, Doctor.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: It should be possible to filter out the human factors.

dialogue: Indeed. I would estimate the odds

dialogue: Doctor.

dialogue: Rigelian physiology is very similar to Vulcan.

dialogue: But it does look promising.

dialogue: I consider the safety factor low, but acceptable.

dialogue: It has been used successfully on test subjects on Rigel Five.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: It would seem the only answer.

title: Journey  to Babel

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Spock here.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: I'll be in the brig questioning the Andorian prisoner.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: No, Doctor.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: My first responsibility is to the ship. Our passengers' safety  is by Starfleet order of first importance. We are being followed by an  alien, possibly hostile, vessel. I cannot relinquish command under  these circumstances.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: On what grounds, Doctor? Command requirements do not recognise  personal privilege. I'll be in the brig interrogating the Andorian.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: He has been subjected to questioning under verifier scan and  truth drug. He reveals nothing. I suggest his mind has been so  conditioned as part of a preconceived plan.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Apparently Thelev did.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: I do not know. There is no logic in Thelev's attack upon the  captain. There is no logic in Gav's murder.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Come in.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Mother, when I was commissioned, I took an oath to carry out  responsibilities which were clearly and exactly specified.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Any competent officer can command this ship under normal  circumstances. The circumstances are not normal. We're carrying over  one hundred valuable Federation passengers. We're being pursued by an  alien ship. We're subject to possible attack. There has been murder and  attempted murder on board. I cannot dismiss my duties.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: I know, but this must take precedence. If I could give the  transfusion without loss of time or efficiency, I would.  Sarek understands my reason.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Mother, how can you have lived on Vulcan so long, married a  Vulcan, raised a son on Vulcan, without understanding what it means to  be a Vulcan?

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: It means to adopt a philosophy, a way of life, which is logical  and beneficial. We cannot disregard that philosophy merely for personal  gain, no matter how important that gain might be.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Can you imagine what my father would say if I were to agree, if  I were to give up command of this vessel, jeopardise hundreds of lives,  risk interplanetary war, all for the life of one person?

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Mother

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: I cannot.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Captain?

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Captain, are you quite all right?

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: I must see the captain.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: The alien ship. I've just realised that if their power  utilisation curve is not the norm, it should be possible to identify  them this way. Very important.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Captain, I believe you'll find the alien

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: I think you'll find he's an Orion, Doctor.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Intelligence reports that Orion smugglers have been raiding the  Coridan system.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: The thing that confused me was the power utilisation curve. It  made them seem more powerful than a starship or anything known to us.  That ship was constructed for a suicide mission. Since they never  intended to return to their home base, they could use one hundred  percent power on their attacks. The thing I don't understand is why I  didn't think of it earlier.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: That hardly seems likely.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Emotional, isn't she?

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Indeed? Why did you marry her?

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Doctor, I'll return to my station now.

title: Journey  to Babel
dialogue: Indeed, Captain. I've never seen him look so happy.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: The only answers are negative. No magnetic storms, no ionic  interference, no breakdown in your equipment.

dialogue: We shall continue sensor scans, Doctor. At the moment, that is  all we can do, except hope for a rational explanation.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: They are not within the confines of this  solar system.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: I have never heard of a study being done, but it would be a  fascinating project.

dialogue: Precisely.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: No. I would say approximately four hundred

dialogue: I would welcome a suggestion, Doctor, even an emotional one, as  to where to look.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Captain's log, stardate 3259.2. First  Officer Spock in command. The Captain, Lieutenant Uhura, and Ensign  Chekov have been missing for nearly two hours. Computer probability  projections are useless due to insufficient data.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Interesting. It seems to be an ionisation trail.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Exactly the question I have just fed to the computers, Doctor.  And the answer is, nothing known to us would account for it.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Plot a follow course, Ensign Haines.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Doctor, I am chasing the Captain, Lieutenant Uhura, and Ensign  Chekov, not some wild aquatic fowl. This is the only lead we've had.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Initiate. Warp factor two.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Projecting back along the path of ionisation, the nearest system  is M two four alpha.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Eleven point six three zero.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: I'm suggesting nothing, Doctor. I am merely pursuing the only  logical course available to us.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: We searched the area.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Such as a failure in the transporter mechanism?

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: There was no sign of them in the area of Gamma Two.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: In that case, Doctor, we have nothing to lose by pursuing our  present course.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Mister Scott, can we manage anything faster  than warp six?

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Doctor, I do not respond to hunches. No transporter malfunction  was responsible for the disappearance. They were not within the Gamma  system. A focused beam of extremely high-intensity light was directed  into the Gamma system from the trinary system we are now approaching.  No known natural phenomena could have caused that beam. Does that  clarify the situation?

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: I see.  Gentlemen, I am in command of this vessel, and we  shall continue on our present course.  Unless  it is your intention to declare a mutiny.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Agreed. Mister Scott, could you manage warp seven?

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Ensign, warp seven.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Sensors indicate only one concentration of life forms on the  planet, on the lower hemisphere. Humanoid readings.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: There will be no landing force, Doctor. Assuming the captain and  the others are still alive, it would be unwise to endanger them by  beaming down a large contingent.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: Interesting. No power source. It may be shielded.

title: The  Gamesters Of Triskelion
dialogue: I shall beam down, Doctor. If I am unable to communicate, a  landing party may be necessary.

dialogue: Daniel, as I recall, had only his faith. But I welcome your  company, Doctor. Mister Scott, you'll be in command.

dialogue: Fascinating.

dialogue: Twenty one point four times as hard, to be exact.

title: Obsession

title: Return  To Tomorrow

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Then you intend to construct mechanical bodies, move your minds  into them, and then return our bodies to us.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Captain, do you know what happened? Do you remember any part of  it?

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Once inside their mechanical bodies, engineer, they can leave  this planet, travel back with us. With their knowledge, mankind could  leap ahead ten thousand years.

title: Return  To Tomorrow

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Hello. Oh, you are a lovely  female. A pleasant sight to wake up to after half a million years.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: You're welcome.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: This is an excellent body, Doctor. I seem to have received the  best of the three. Strength, hearing, eyesight, all far above your  human norms. I'm surprised the Vulcans never conquered your race.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Yes, of course, Just as we do, Doctor.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: It will be unnecessary, Doctor. This Vulcan body is accustomed  to the higher metabolism.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: I'll prepare the formula, Sargon.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: I can continue in this body for several hours.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: This woman will assist me.  You will take me to your  pharmacology laboratory.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Now. this formula will reduce the heart  action and the bodily functions to normal. While the bodies are  occupied, you will administer one injection of ten cc's each hour.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: This hypo you will code mark for Thalassa. And this one you will  code mark for me.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: This one you will administer to Captain Kirk while Sargon is in  his body.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: No, that's correct. But since I will arrange for you to  administer each of the injections, no one else will notice.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: What were you saying?

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Yes. Well, you were about to say that you watched me prepare the  formula and fill each of the hypos.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Very good. You see, Sargon would not permit me to keep this  body. It is therefore necessary for you to kill your captain  so that Sargon will die with him.   Enterprise Medical Log. Stardate 4769.1. Three  alien minds now inhabit the bodies of Captain Kirk, Science Officer  Spock, and Doctor Ann Mulhall.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: In two days, you'll have your own hands, Thalassa. Mechanically  efficient and quite human-looking. Android robot hands, of course.  Hands without feeling. Enjoy the taste of life while you can.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: It will have twice the strength and agility of your body,  engineer, and will last a thousand years. That is, assuming you'll stop  wasting your time and allow us to complete it.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: A thousand-year prison, Thalassa. And when it wears out we'll  build another one, and we'll lock ourselves into it for another  thousand years. And another, and another. Sargon has closed his mind to  a better way. With these bodies.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: When you awoke in this body, Thalassa, you said how good it was  to breathe again, to have eyes and to see again. To feel. To live and  feel again, Thalassa. Just think how much we can do for mankind. Are  these bodies too much to ask for in return? Would you prefer this?

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: This is your new home, Thalassa. Once occupied, I'll add female  features and some texturing. You no doubt want the mechanism to at  least appear to be a woman.  It is ready,  Thalassa.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: You have no excuse to keep the real body any longer. Sargon  would've required that you enter the mechanism immediately.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Must I make an example of you, too, Helm?

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Pain, Captain. And you, my dear?

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Fortunately, Doctor, I know every thought of every mind around  me. See?  Take the hypo from him. And inject him with it.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Fools. I'll simply transfer to another place, another body.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: Sargon! No, Sargon, please. Let me. Let me transfer.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: It seems, Doctor, the injection was only enough to cause  unconsciousness.

title: Return  To Tomorrow
dialogue: The place Henoch would least suspect, Captain.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Passing outer planet, Zeon.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: I never met John Gill, but I studied Earth history from the text  he prepared.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: What impressed me most was his treatment of Earth history as  causes and motivations rather than dates and events.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Yes, but it must be a Zeon ship. Zeons do have a crude  interplanetary capability. Reaction powered. A small rocket. It is on  an intercept course. That would mean it has sophisticated detection  devices which neither Zeon nor Ekos should have.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Captain, it's an unmanned probe which seems to be carrying a  warhead.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Fascinating. A thermonuclear warhead.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Most interesting. We were attacked by a thermonuclear missile  from a planet which should have no such weapon.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: According to our records, the Ekosians are a primitive, warlike  people in a state of anarchy. The other planet, Zeon, has a relatively  high technology, and its people are peaceful.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Ready, Captain.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: The Ekosians are humanoid, so there is apt to be a similarity in  architecture. Interesting.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Captain, the non-interference Directive.

title: Patterns  Of Force

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Virtually impossible, Captain, yet the evidence is quite clear.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: You propose we pass ourselves off as Nazis, Captain?

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: That's very well taken, Captain.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Yes. Obviously he's not one of us. I captured him. Is that not  correct procedure with enemies of the Fatherland?

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Take charge of him.

title: Patterns  Of Force

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Quite correct. You should make a very convincing Nazi.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Obviously.

title: Patterns  Of Force

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: That would coincide with the time of John Gill's arrival.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Captain, the flaw in the plan is this locked door, and the guard  beyond it. To the logical mind, the outlook is somewhat gloomy.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Yes.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Of course. The rubindium crystals in the transponders.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Yes. We must hold the crystals rigidly at a specific distance,  which I believe should be twenty seven point two millimetres.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Twenty seven point two millimetres would be, approximately,  there. That is, of course, a crude estimation.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Yes. To reach that light, I shall require some sort of platform.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Now, the rubindium crystals should find enough power here to  achieve the necessary stimulus. As I recall from the history of  physics, the ancient lasers were able to achieve the necessary  excitation, even using crude natural crystals.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Yes, of course, Captain. You realise that the aim will of course  be very crude.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Captain, why should I aim at such a structure?

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: May I remind you, we did not intend to fight.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Possibly.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: I do not see them.

dialogue: Captain, without phasers, and until we are able to communicate  with the ship, it is illogical to assume that we can hold out against  the entire military force of this planet.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Captain, I suggest the most profitable use of our time would be  to reassemble our communicators. May I work undisturbed somewhere?

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: By using parts from both, I've completed one communicator. I do  not know if the circuits are correct, Captain. There is no way to test  it, except in actual use.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: The one receiving a medal.

title: Patterns  Of Force

dialogue: As an honoured member of the Party, she could get us past the  guards.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Captain, I'm beginning to understand why you  Earthmen enjoy gambling. No matter how carefully one computes the odds  of success, there is still a certain exhilaration in the risk.

dialogue: There is a logical way to proceed, Doctor. Point your toe, apply  equal pressure to either side of the boot, and push. We have no time  for emotionalism.

dialogue: Captain. I have created a condition in which Gill cannot  initiate speech or any other action, but he can reply to questions.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Quite true, Captain. That tiny country, beaten, bankrupt,  defeated, rose in a few years to stand only one step away from global  domination.

title: Patterns  Of Force
dialogue: Perhaps Gill felt that such a state, run benignly, could  accomplish its efficiency without sadism.

dialogue: Is he dead, Captain?

title: Patterns  Of Force

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Commodore Wesley. How do you do, sir?

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: The most ambitious computer complex ever created. Its purpose is  to correlate all computer activity aboard a starship, to provide the  ultimate in vessel operation and control.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I hold an A-7 computer expert classification, Commodore. I'm  well acquainted with Doctor Daystrom's theories and discoveries. The  basic design of all our ship's computers are Doctor Daystrom's.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: We are attempting to prove it can run this ship more efficiently  than man.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: The most unfortunate lack in current computer programming is  that there is nothing available to immediately replace the starship  surgeon.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I am honoured, Doctor.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Fascinating, Doctor. This computer has a potential beyond  anything you've ever done. Even your breakthrough in duotronics did not  have the promise of this.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: The M-5 has been perfected, Commander. Its potential is a fact.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: If I can be of assistance, Doctor.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: M-5 has performed admirably so far.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Captain, I am forced to agree with Doctor Daystrom. With the  course information plotted into it, his computer could have brought us  here as easily as the navigator. In fact, it might have been a further  demonstration of M-5's capability.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Enjoy, Captain? No. I'm merely gratified to see Doctor  Daystrom's new unit execute everything required of it in such a highly  efficient manner. M-5 is another distinguished triumph for his career.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: The planet is class M, Captain. Oxygen-nitrogen atmosphere  suitable for human life support. Two major land masses, a number of  islands, life form readings.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: M-5's readout, Captain.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Captain, the computer does not judge. It makes logical  selections.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I am not familiar with these instruments, Doctor. You are using  an entirely new type of control mechanism. However, it appears to me  this unit is drawing more power than before.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Doctor, this unit is not a human body. The computer can process  information, but only the information which is put into it.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Captain, sensors report two contacts now. One on the port bow,  one on the stern. Distance, two hundred  thousand kilometres and closing.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: We are not scheduled for war games in this area. This may be a  surprise attack as a problem for the M-5.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Phaser hit on port deflector four, Captain.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Attacking vessels are moving off.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Minor hit on deflector screen four. No appreciable damage.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: The ship reacted more rapidly than human control could have  manoeuvred her. Tactics, deployment of weapons, all indicate an immense  sophistication in computer control.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Practical, Captain? Perhaps. But not desirable. Computers make  excellent and efficient servants, but I have no wish to serve under  them. Captain the starship also runs on loyalty to one man, and nothing  can replace it, or him.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Dunsel, Doctor, is a term used by midshipmen at Starfleet  Academy. It refers to a part which serves no useful purpose.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Unidentified. This is not a drill.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: M-5 has identified her, Captain. The Woden. Listed in Starfleet  Registry as an old-style ore freighter converted to automation. No  crew. Coming into visual range.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: No effect on any of the M-5 controls, Captain.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Captain, photon torpedoes locking on target. Full power.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: All systems report normal, Captain.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I would say, Captain, that M-5 is not only capable of taking  care of this ship, it is also capable of taking care of itself.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: M-5 appears drawing power directly from the warp engines,  tapping the matter-antimatter reserves.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: The multitronic unit is drawing more and more power directly  from the warp engines. The computer now controls all helm, navigation,  and engineering functions.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: There is one possibility. The automatic helm navigation circuit  relays might be disrupted from engineering level three.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Most illogical. Of all people, he should have known how the  computer would perform. Of course, the M-5 itself has not behaved  logically.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: No. But it is interesting.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Good.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Mister Scott is ready to apply the circuit disrupter. As he does  so, I shall trip the manual override into control.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Manual override is in control, Captain.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Mister Chekov.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Thank you, Ensign.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: It appears, Captain, we've been doing  what used to be called pursuing a wild goose. M-5 has rerouted helm and  navigational controls, bypassing this primary system.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I believe that when M-5 discovered our tampering, it rerouted  the controls, leaving this one active by simply sending through an  electronic impulse at regular intervals.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I do not know. It is not performing in a logical manner.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I do not mean to offend, sir, but it behaves with an almost  human pattern.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Attack force closing rapidly, breaking formation, attacking at  will.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Hit on the Lexington.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Hit in engineering section. Possible damage to her impulse  engines. She's still maneuverable on warp drive.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: The Excalibur, a direct hit.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Lexington hit again.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Probably true, Captain. It works faster, thinks faster than we  do. It is a human mind amplified by the instantaneous relays possible  in a computer.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Doctor Daystrom, you impressed human engrams on the M-5  circuits.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Then perhaps you could talk to the unit. M-5 has no reason to  believe you would harm it.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I am most impressed with the technology, Captain. Doctor  Daystrom has created a mirror image of his mind.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Every living thing wants to survive, Captain. Daystrom must have  impressed that instinctive reaction upon the computer.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Commodore Wesley is a dedicated commander. I should regret  serving aboard the instrument of his death.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Captain, attack force almost within phaser range.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: M-5 is leaving itself open to attack. The machine is committing  suicide to atone for the sin of murder.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: The force field is gone, Captain. M-5 is  neutralised.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I would say his multitronic unit is in approximately the same  condition.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: Captain, why did you feel the attacking ships would not fire  when they saw the Enterprise apparently vulnerable? Logically, that is  the sort of trap M-5 should have set.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: No, Doctor. I simply maintain that computers are more efficient  than human beings, not better.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: I presume your question is meant to offer me a choice between  machines and human beings, and I believe I have already answered that  question.

title: The  Ultimate Computer
dialogue: It would be most interesting to impress your memory engrams on a  computer, Doctor. The resulting torrential flood of illogic would be  most entertaining.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: We're locked onto the Exeter's engineering  section, Captain.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Captain.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: As if they were in them when

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Lieutenant Galloway and I are checking out  the lower levels. There seems to be no one aboard. Only uniforms.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Aye, sir.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: I have their surgeon's log, Captain. Their last log entry,  Captain, on screen.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Interesting that the villagers know about phasers.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: A Yang lance, Doctor.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Bruised only. We were approximately one hundred metres from the  village when five of the savages ambushed us. We managed to escape  without firing.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Captain Tracey is being quite factual in several statements.  One, the Yangs are totally contemptuous of death. They seem incredibly  vicious. Two, he is also being factual in that the Yangs are massing  for an attack. There are signs of thousands of them in the foothills  beyond. However, he was less than truthful in one very important  matter.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Captain Tracey's reserve belt packs. Empty. Found among the  remains of several hundred Yang bodies.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: A smaller attack on this village a week ago, driven off by  Captain Tracey with his phaser. I have found villagers who will  corroborate it.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Regulations are quite harsh, but they're also quite clear,  Captain. If you do not act, you will be considered equally guilty.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: I agree that formal charges have little meaning now. However,  you must at least confiscate his phaser.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Not that I have observed, Captain. Of course, should they wish  to do so, one could always rest while the other keeps you occupied.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Good, Captain. Try to reason with them. Keep trying, Captain.  Their behaviour is highly illogical.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: I have tried, Captain.  {Storeroom]

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Captain, I have managed to loosen this grill  somewhat. If the mortar on yours is as old.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Captain Tracey mentioned there was once a considerable  civilisation here. The only reasonable explanation would be a war.  Nuclear devastation or a bacteriological holocaust.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Yes, I heard, Captain.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Captain? Captain? Captain, are you able to respond?

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Seven hours and eight minutes, Captain.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: We can contact the ship in a few moments, Captain, if I can  cross-circuit this unit.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: War created an imbalance and nature counterbalanced it.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Ready, Captain. Quite crude. Voice communication will not be  possible, but we can signal the ship.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: I'm weak, Captain, but not in difficulty.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: My need for attention is vital, Doctor, but our need for  departure is even more immediate.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Yes. I see, Captain. They would've learned to wear skins,  adopted stoic mannerisms, learned the bow and the lance.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: Kohms? Communists? The parallel is almost too close, Captain. It  would mean they fought the war your Earth avoided, and in this case,  the Asiatics won and took over this planet.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: I am open to suggestions, Doctor.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: I'm making a suggestion.

title: The  Omega Glory
dialogue: There's no question about his guilt, Captain, but does our  involvement here also constitute a violation of the Prime Directive?

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: It appears we have accidentally intercepted someone's  transporter beam, Captain.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Captain, something is beaming aboard this  vessel.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: The beam is originating at least one  thousand light years away.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: If what he says is true, Captain, every second we delay him  could be dangerous.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: A most difficult decision, Captain.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Quite a lovely animal, Captain. I find myself strangely drawn to  it.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: He did say his planet was hidden, Captain.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Current Earth crises would fill a tape bank, Captain. There will  be an important assassination today, an equally dangerous government  coup in Asia, and, this could be highly critical, the launching of an  orbital nuclear warhead platform by the United States countering a  similar launch by other powers.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Most definitely. Once the sky was full of orbiting H-bombs, the  slightest mistake could have brought one down by accident,  setting off a nuclear holocaust.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: He might be inclined to prepare a perfect one, Captain. But then  again he may be telling the truth.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Following him down is a major risk, Captain. If we ourselves do  anything that changes history

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: In here, Captain.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Chances are he's out of sight inside the rocket gantry or at one  of the control centres.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Here, let me help you, Sergeant. It's operated with this dial  here.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: I can try, Captain.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: I can estimate some of this, Captain, but without more time

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: It is difficult to know which is best, Captain.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Without facts, the decision cannot be made logically. You must  rely on your human intuition.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Correction, Mister Seven. It appears we did not interfere. The  Enterprise was part of what was supposed to happen on this day in 1968.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: And you'll be pleased our records show that it resulted in a new  and stronger international agreement against the use of such weapons.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Captain, we could say that Mister Seven and Miss Lincoln have  some interesting experiences in store for them.

title: Assignment:  Earth
dialogue: Live long and prosper, Mister Seven.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: On mark eight and closing.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: A mechanical device of unknown properties. I read no life forms  aboard.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Obviously, it intends to intercept us. It has made several  course changes corresponding with our own.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Unclear whether it intends to attack or merely communicate with  us.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Indeed.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Vulcan, Captain.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Unquestionably. Most impressive.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: True telepaths can be most formidable, and we have been warned.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: No recorded contacts. If they ever ventured into space, they  evidently withdrew immediately.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: I prefer being a welcomed guest, Captain, but there seems to be  little choice.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Unknown, Captain. Sensor readings give no indication of fog like  conditions in this area.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Unknown, Captain. Unlike Mister Scott's transporter, this unit  is not functioning.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: No use, Captain. Obviously none of our devices will function.  Apparently that Melkotian buoy

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Obviously this represents the Melkotian's concept of an American  frontier town, circa 1880.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Perhaps the Melkotians have insufficient data about this era.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Crude but dangerous.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain, the Melkot said you were the pattern. He looked into  your mind and selected what he considered the proper time and place for  our punishment.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Yes. The violence of your own heritage is to be the pattern for  our execution.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Precisely, in terms of what the Melkots intend for us.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Are they really?

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain, I pride myself on my knowledge of your Earth history.  The names were known in the annals of the opening of the western sector  of America. the United States of America, that is.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: And the Clanton gang. On October 26th, they had it out.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: History cannot be changed.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Is this a dead man, Doctor?

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain, since we have seen that death is the one reality in  this situation, I seriously suggest you reseat yourself immediately.  Without moving a muscle of either hand. If I remember correctly, that  would involve you in what was called the fast draw. It initiated  unfortunate events.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: I believe he was actually trying to provoke a dispute with  Mister Chekov.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: I assure you, sir, we shall watch it, and everything, extremely  closely.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: The day is still young, Ensign.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: And if this is indeed some sort of replay of history, the Earps  will kill the Clantons at the OK Corral at five o'clock this afternoon.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Impossible, Captain. In this century, there are no metal alloys  or power sources to make devices such as ours.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Mister Chekov is involved, Captain.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: It is obvious the Melkotians are not going to permit us to leave  this town.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: There's no way we can know where it is, Doctor.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: I could make a device to deliver it on target.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: I shall need some fusing and cotton wadding.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: I shall manufacture the equivalent of an ancient generating  canister, more familiarly known as a gas grenade.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: And it is not yet our time.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Gentlemen, there is one thing which requires the immediate  attention of all of us. Specifically, our future.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: I understand the feeling, Captain.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: My feelings are not a subject for discussion, Doctor.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain, it's quite all right. They forget I am half human.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain. I vaguely remember the historical account of the famous  battle in which we are about to engage, but I am confused.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Since each of us represents members of the Clanton gang. You,  Ike Clanton, I, Frank McLowery, then Mister Chekov would be the other  Billy, would he not?

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: But did not William Claiborne survive the battle at the OK  Corral?

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Mister Chekov is dead. But in the actual gunfight, William  Claiborne survived.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Another hour.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Not precisely.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: It should.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Negotiating with them could buy us more time, Captain.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: It would be worth a try, at least until we're certain of the  device. Then perhaps we could quiet things down.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: These crude supplies we were forced to use  worked quite well.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Perhaps they would've been if they'd had your ingenuity, Doctor.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain?

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Right now.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: It has not been tested.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: But this is painless.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain, you don't seem to understand. It did not function, but  it must function.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: A scientific fact But if the tranquilliser does not function,  which is clearly impossible, then a radical alteration of our thought  patterns must be in order.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: That may not be necessary.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: A fact, Captain. Physical laws simply cannot be ignored.  Existence cannot be without them.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: I mean, Doctor, that we are faced with a staggering  contradiction. The tranquilliser you created should have been  effective.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Exactly. Doctor, in your opinion, what killed Mister Chekov?

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Wrong. His mind killed him.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Physical reality is consistent with universal laws. Where the  laws do not operate, there is no reality. All of this is unreal.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: But you made your examination under conditions which we cannot  trust. We judge reality by the response of our senses.  Once we are convinced of the reality of a given situation, we abide by  its rules. We judged the bullets to be solid, the guns to be real,  therefore they can kill.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: He may indeed be dead. We do not know.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Exactly. I know the bullets are unreal, therefore they cannot  harm me.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Precisely.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: The smallest doubt would be enough to kill you.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Very well, sir. Engineer?

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Your mind to my mind. Your thoughts to my thoughts.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: The bullets are unreal. Without body. They are  illusions only. Shadows without substance. They will not pass through  your body, for they do not exist.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain, the Melkotian object.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: The object is beginning to emit M-rays of a highly unstable  nature, Captain.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Energy output increasing beyond measurable levels, Captain.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Captain. May I ask a question? You needn't answer if it seems  too personal.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: This afternoon, you wanted to kill, didn't you?

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: But he wanted to, Doctor.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Yes, Captain.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: Mankind, ready to kill.

title: Spectre  Of The Gun
dialogue: I wonder how humanity managed to survive.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: It's in a border area, Mister Scott. The Klingons also claim  jurisdiction.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Sounds typical of the Elasians. The scientists who made the  initial investigation reported the men were vicious and arrogant.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Not without precedent, Captain. Remember that

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: I am the first officer. This is Captain James Kirk.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Captain, the Dohlman is dissatisfied with the quarters provided.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: I do not know, but all the Elasians seem most irrational.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: At first it appeared to be a sensor ghost,  but I've run checks on all the instrumentation. All the equipment is  functioning perfectly.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: None in this area. Nothing that would account for it. The ghost  appears intermittently.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: None, Captain. Insufficient data.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Captain, we had a momentary fix on the object enough to  establish it was a spaceship.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: No data yet.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Our ghost has materialised.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Negative, Captain. The Klingon ship has simply moved into  contact range. She is pacing us, precisely matching our sublight speed  and on a parallel course.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Captain, your analysis of the situation was flawless,  anticipating that she would deny you admittance. However, the logic by  which you arrived at your conclusion escapes me.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: I have it on my sensor, Lieutenant.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: May we see you a moment?

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Captain, are you all right?

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: It is true then, Captain?

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Their speed is better than warp six, Captain.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: I don't think they meant to attack us. We were very fortunate  this time.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Very. But why do the Klingons consider the possession of this  system so vital?

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: I have another question, Captain. Is not the bridge the wrong  place for the Dohlman at a time like this?

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: They demand an immediate reply.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: We can still manoeuvre.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Help could not arrive before the Enterprise would be destroyed.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: He's passed us. All shields held.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Better than warp seven.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: He's past us again. Damage to number four shield.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: It will not withstand another full charge, Captain. I'm getting  some very peculiar energy readings.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: She is the source.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: The necklace.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: These are common stones?  See, Captain? Here and  here.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: No doubt, Captain.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Captain, these are crude crystals. There is  no way to judge what the unusual shapes will do to the energy flow.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: Damage to Klingon number three shield. Number four shield  obliterated. Loss of manoeuvre power.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: You are too late, Doctor. The Captain has found his own  antidote.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: The antidote to a woman of Elas, Doctor, is a starship. The  Enterprise infected the Captain long before the Dohlman did.

title: Elaan  of Troyius
dialogue: In this particular instance, Doctor, I agree with you.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Astronomical, Captain. The relative size, age and composition of  this planet makes it highly improbable that it would evolve similarly  to Earth in any way.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: An alien metal of some kind. An alloy resistant to probe.  Readings can't even measure its age accurately. These incised symbols  are fascinating. Evidently, some form of writing.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Negative, Captain. Structures of this complexity require  extremely sophisticated building apparatus, the kind usually found in  cultures surpassing or equalling our own.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Bearing one one seven mark four.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: If we are to divert the asteroid which is on a collision course  with this planet, we must warp out of orbit within thirty minutes.  Every second we delay arriving at the deflection point compounds the  problem, perhaps past solution.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Yes, sir.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: They are, Doctor. A mixture of Navajo, Mohican, and Delaware, I  believe. All among the more advanced and peaceful tribes.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Highly improbable, Captain. Sensor probes indicate only one type  of life form here.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Too primitive to grasp the concept of space flight, Doctor. Our  appearance here would only confuse and frighten them.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Doctor?

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I suggest that any further research on your part be delayed  until after we have diverted the asteroid.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Spock to Enterprise.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Prepare to beam us up, Mister Scott. We're warping out of orbit.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Doctor, that asteroid is almost as large as your Earth's moon.  Far enough away, the angle necessary to divert it enough to avoid  destruction is minute, but as the asteroid approaches this planet, the  angle becomes so great that even the power of a starship

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: If we arrive at the deflection point in time, it may not get  here at all.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Once the asteroid has been diverted, we'll return here and  resume the search.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Doctor, assume  this is the planet we're on. This is the approaching asteroid. If we  don't get to that deflection point in time, it will become physically  impossible to divert this asteroid. In that case, everyone on this  planet will die, including the captain.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: In the time it's taken me to explain the problem, the asteroid  has moved from here to here. The longer we delay, the less the  likelihood of being able to divert it. Beam us up, Mister Scott.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Stress or not, we cannot reduce speed. I do  not intend to miss that

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Objection noted, Mister Scott. Carry on.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Then bypass the relays and go to manual control.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I want full power, Mister Scott.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Magnification factor twelve, Mister Sulu.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: All engines stop. Hold position here.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Prepare to activate deflectors.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Engineering, maintain full power. Full power.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Not now.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Activate deflectors.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Degree of deflection, Mister Sulu.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Recircuit power to engines. Maximum speed heading three seven  mark zero one zero.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Correct, Mister Chekov. I intend to retreat in front of that  asteroid until we can employ all power on phaser beams.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: To destroy it. A narrow beam concentrated on a single spot will  split that mass.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Incorrect. We'll still be able to get out of its path by use of  impulse power.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: That, Doctor, is another calculated risk we must take.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Co-ordinates, Mister Chekov.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: That is our target. The asteroid's weakest point.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Lock all phasers on that mark. Maximum intensity, narrow beam. I  want to split that fissure wide open.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Very astute, Doctor.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: We'll fire in sequence and continue firing as long as Mister  Scott can maintain power.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Fire phasers.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Rig for simultaneous firing, Mister Sulu. Commence simultaneous  bombardment.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Estimated repair time?  {Engineering]

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I've already surmised that. Thank you, Mister Scott.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I accept the responsibility, Doctor.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Mister Chekov, resume heading eight eight three mark four one.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Exactly fifty nine point two two three days, Doctor, and that  asteroid will be four hours behind us all the way.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Another calculated Vulcan risk, Doctor.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: There isn't time, Doctor. I must decipher those obelisk's  symbols. They're a highly advanced form of cipher writing.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I'm aware of that, Doctor. I'm also aware when we arrive at the  planet, we'll have barely four hours to effect rescue. I believe those  symbols are the key.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I am not hungry, Doctor. And under stress, we Vulcans can do  without sleep for weeks.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: My physical condition is not important, Doctor. That obelisk is.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: You prescribed rest, Doctor. The symbols on the obelisk are not  words. They are musical notes.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: In a way, yes. Other cultures, among them certain Vulcan  offshoots, use musical notes as words. The tones correspond roughly to  an alphabet.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Yes. The obelisk is a marker, just as I thought. It was left by  a super-race known as the Preservers. They passed through the galaxy  rescuing primitive cultures which were in danger of extinction and  seeding them, so to speak, where they could live and grow.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: So have I. Apparently the Preservers account for a number of  them.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Which has now become defective and is failing to operate.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Precisely, Doctor.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Spock to Enterprise.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: We've located the captain. Beam down Nurse Chapel with an  emergency surgical kit.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Hallucinations?

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: The nurse has given you something to ease the pain. Why were you  being stoned?

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Naturally, since he did not come from there.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Time, Doctor McCoy, is the one thing we do not have in  abundance.  Spock here.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Report noted. Doctor, is he strong enough for the Vulcan mind  fusion?

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I am Spock. You are James Kirk. Our minds are moving closer.  Closer, closer, closer, James Kirk. Closer.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: James Kirk.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Our minds are one.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I am Kir

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Spock!

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: His mind. He is an extremely dynamic individual.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Captain, were you inside this structure?

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: This obelisk is one huge deflector mechanism. It is imperative  that we get inside immediately. Captain, we do not have much time.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: If we are not able to gain entry and activate the deflector  mechanism within the next fifty minutes, this entire planet will be  destroyed.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I already have to some extent, Captain. They are musical notes.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: That would be one method. Another would be a series of tonal  qualities spoken in their proper sequence.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: If you could remember your exact words, Captain.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: It is similar to deflector panels I've seen,  Captain, but far more complicated.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: Probably a memory beam. You must have activated it out of  sequence.

title: The  Paradise Syndrome
dialogue: I do have an excellent eye for musical notes, Captain. They  would seem to indicate that this series of relays activated in their  proper

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I did give a full report

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: No, sir. Compliance presents no problem.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Sensor scan to one half parsec. Negative, Captain.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Increasing sensor scan to one parsec. All scanners report clear.  Nothing in our immediate vicinity.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Intelligence reports Romulans now using Klingon design.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: A second ship has appeared.  Correction,  there are now three. We are surrounded.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I have a theory, Captain.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: True, Captain. That would be standard Romulan procedure.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: It would be a great prize.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I believe the Romulans have developed a cloaking device which  renders our tracking sensors useless.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: If we had not crossed the Neutral Zone, on your order, you would  not now need our opinions to support a decision which should never have  had to be made.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Spock.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I understand.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Starfleet is not in the habit of informing Romulans of its  ships' personnel.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: It is no myth.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I reserve the privilege of speaking only when it will not  violate my honour as a Vulcan.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: You're being clever, Commander. That is unworthy of a Romulan.  It is not a lie to keep the truth to oneself.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: You would not resort to them, Commander. They would prove  ineffective against the captain.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I cannot allow the captain to be further destroyed. The strain  of command has worn heavily upon him. He's not been himself for several  weeks.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: As you can see, Captain Kirk is a highly sensitive and emotional  person. I believe he has lost the capacity for rational decision.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I'm betraying no secrets. The commander's suspicion that  Starfleet ordered the Enterprise into the Neutral Zone is unacceptable.  Our rapid capture demonstrates its foolhardiness.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I am speaking the truth for the benefit of the Enterprise and  the Federation. I say now and for the record, that Captain Kirk ordered  the Enterprise across the Neutral Zone on his own initiative and his  craving for glory.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: He is not sane.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I am half Vulcan. My mother is a human.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Vulcan.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Eighteen years.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: The question is irrelevant.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: My duty as an officer is to obey him.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I do not desire a ship of my own.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Such opportunities are extremely rare.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: That thought has occasionally crossed my mind.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Commander, shall we speak plainly? It is you who desperately  need a ship. You want the Enterprise.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Indeed.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I am honoured, Commander. Are the guards also invited?

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Of course. I shall obey your restrictions.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: It would be illogical to assume that all conditions remain  stable.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I am ready.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: The matter is not open for discussion, Doctor.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: There is no alternative, Doctor. The safety of the crew is now  the paramount issue. It is misguided loyalty to resist any further.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I was unprepared for his attack. I instinctively used the Vulcan  death grip.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I am very flattered, Commander. There's no doubt that the  cuisine aboard your vessel is far superior to that of the Enterprise.  It is indeed a very powerful recruiting inducement.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: A place?

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I was not aware of that aspect of Romulan society.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Please believe me. I do appreciate it.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Yes, of course, but not just this moment. An hour from now will  do even better. Would it not, Commander?

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I was beginning to wonder.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: How rare, and how beautiful. But so incongruous when spoken by a  soldier.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Spock to Captain Kirk.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Captain

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Yes, Captain. The cloaking device is in an  area near the commander's quarters. It is closely guarded and  off-limits to all but authorised personnel. What is your present  location?

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Unknown, Captain. At present, I am rather  heavily

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Commander, your attire is not only more appropriate, it should  actually stimulate our conversation.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I must confess that I too am moved emotionally. I know it is  illogical.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: That will be profitless, Commander. I do not believe you will  find it.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I assure you I am quite sane.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: First officer of the Enterprise.  What is your present form of execution?   Captain's log, stardate 5027.4. Commander Scott has  less than fifteen minutes to install the Romulan's cloaking device and  get it working. I hope Mister Spock can buy us the time we need.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: I demand the Right of Statement first.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Thank you. I shall not require much time. No more than twenty  minutes, I should say.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: My crime is sabotage. I freely admit my guilt.  The oath I swore as a Starfleet officer is both  specific and binding. As long as I wear the uniform, my duty is to  protect the security of the Federation. Clearly, your new cloaking  device is a threat to that security. I carried out my duty.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: There is no regulation regarding the content of my statement.  May I continue?

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Beyond the historic tradition of Vulcan  loyalty, there is also the combined Romulan-Vulcan history of obedience  to duty.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: One hundred and fifty thousand kilometres, Captain, and closing  very rapidly.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: One hundred thousand kilometres. They should commence firing at  us within the next twelve point seven seconds.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: The cloaking device is working perfectly, and the commander has  informed me that even the Romulan sensors cannot track a vessel so  equipped.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Deck two. It is regrettable that you were  made an unwilling passenger. It was not intentional. All the Federation  wanted was the cloaking device.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: It was my only interest when I boarded your vessel.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: You underestimate yourself, Commander.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Obviously. Military secrets are the most fleeting of all. I hope  that you and I exchanged something more permanent.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: It was the only choice possible. You would not respect any  other.

title: The  Enterprise Incident
dialogue: Captain, please go. Somehow they do not look aesthetically  agreeable

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Humans do have an amazing capacity for believing what they  choose and excluding that which is painful.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: The attack on Professor Starnes' party must surely have been  unprovoked.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: I stand corrected, Captain. Induced would be a more precise  term. Induced by an outside force.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: The release of bacteria. Or a helpless mental depression and a  state of suicidal anxiety could have been chemically induced.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: I do not know, but it is possible.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: A valid assumption, I would say.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Or the promise of reward.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: At present, yes.  Odd.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: There seems to be some disturbance coming from that cave.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Definitely not humanoid, Captain. Impossible to make any  specific identification. The readings do not correlate with any known  information.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: I'm not aware of it, Captain.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: I am not familiar with anxiety, but I wasn't aware it could be  registered on sensors.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Are you all right, Captain?

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Captain, I have extracted the salient portion of  Professor Starnes' tapes.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Among the technical facts he gathered, Professor Starnes also  offered some rather unscientific hypotheses.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: There is another portion, Captain, which I believe you'll find  particularly interesting.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Unknown.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: He never completed the entry, and the dispatch was never sent.  Except for scenes of family life, games and picnics with the children,  that is the complete record. Whatever overwhelmed them must have done  so with incredible speed. Otherwise, the professor would have provided  details of the experience. He was an excellent scientist and tireless  in his pursuit of the truth.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Possible, Captain. Evil does seek to maintain power by  suppressing the truth.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: According to the legend, Triacus was the seat of a band of  marauders who made constant war throughout the system of Epsilon Indi.  After many centuries, the destroyers were themselves destroyed by those  they had preyed upon.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: No, like so many legends, this one too has a frightening ending.  It warns that the evil is awaiting a catalyst to set it again into  motion and send it marauding across the galaxy.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: I was speaking of a legend, Captain.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: According to Federation records, this is the first.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: He said an unseen force was influencing him, that he recognised  it, was beginning to fight it and cancelled his request for a ship.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: I am unable to lock on to the proper co-ordinates.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: It appears we are no longer orbiting Triacus.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Captain, we are no longer orbiting Triacus.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Captain, why are we bothering Starfleet?

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: This bridge is under complete control.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: There is no need.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: I cannot obey your order, Captain.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Captain, we must get off this bridge.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Captain.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Jim.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Correct, Captain.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Where to, Captain?

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Captain, so long as the children are present, there is danger.  They are the carriers.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: They are followers. Without followers, evil cannot spread.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Captain, the four hundred and thirty men and women on board the  Enterprise and the ship itself are endangered by these children.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Perhaps that is true, but the evil that is within them is  spreading fast, and unless we can find a way to remove it

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: You take from those who do not know you.

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Why should you fear it?

title: And  The Children Shall Lead
dialogue: Tommy's father would have destroyed you, but he recognised you  too late.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Configuration unidentified. Ion propulsion, high velocity,  though of a unique technology.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: One. Humanoid or similar. Low level of activity. Life-support  systems functioning. Interior atmosphere, conventional nitrogen-oxygen.  Instruments indicate a transferal beam emanating from the area of the  humanoid life form.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Directed at the Bridge of the Enterprise, Captain.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Yes. Doctor McCoy.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: If you will finish reconnecting my speech centre, I might be  able to help.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Yes. That's correct. One thing at a time. Ah, ah, mmm.  That's better. Now, Doctor. Try the sonic separator.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Yes, I believe I already have some sensation of feeling. Please  stimulate the nerve endings and observe the physical reactions, one by  one. In each case, I shall tell you when the probe is correct. You will  then seal using the tri-laser connector.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Ready.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Correct.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Correct.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Correct. Very good, Doctor.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: Congratulations, Doctor. And thank you.

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: On the whole, Captain, I believe I am quite fit. Fascinating. A  remarkable example of a retrograde civilisation. At the peak, advanced  beyond any of our capabilities and now operating at this primitive  level which you saw. And it all began thousands of years ago when a  glacial age reoccurred. This underground complex was developed for the  women. The men remained above, and a male-female schism took place. A  fascinating cultural development of a kind which never

title: Spock's  Brain
dialogue: As I was saying, a fascinating cultural  development of the kind which hasn't been seen in ages. The last such  occurrence took place on old Earth, when the Romans were warring with  the ....

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Thank you, Mister Marvick. I shall be wearing the visor.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: It has proved effective for Vulcans.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I shall endeavour to keep it under control.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Welcome aboard, Ambassador Kollos. I am First Officer Spock.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Captain Kirk, we are ready.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Doctor Jones, may I congratulate you on your assignment with  Ambassador Kollos.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I'm sure you will find it a fascinating experience.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: No one ever has. I was referring to mind-links I had attempted  with members of other species.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I was unable to accept. My life is here.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Spock to Bridge. We have arrived at the Ambassador's quarters.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I would appreciate an opportunity to exchange greetings with the  Ambassador.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I almost envy you your assignment.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Not correct, Doctor, although I am aware of your mind attempting  to contact mine. Were you born a telepath?

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I understand. May I show you to your quarters?

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I understand. Our ship's surgeon often makes the same complaint.  Do call when you are ready.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Why, thank you, Captain.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: On the contrary, Doctor, I would say that Doctor Jones was  indeed fortunate.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Doctor Jones was born a telepath, Captain.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: What most humans generally find impossible to understand is the  need to shut out the bedlam of other people's thoughts and emotions.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: As a matter of fact, I wear it this evening to honour you,  Doctor.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I see, Doctor McCoy, you still subscribe to the outmoded notion,  promulgated by your ancient Greeks, that what is good must also be  beautiful.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I'll escort you to your quarters.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I genuinely intended to honour her, Captain. Good evening,  gentlemen.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Do you know whether he saw the Medusan?

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Then insanity will surely be the result, Captain. Dangerous  insanity.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Trying, Captain. Mister Chekov, your assistance, please.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: We are evidently far outside our own galaxy, judging from the  lack of traceable reference points. When we exceeded warp speed factor  nine point five, we apparently entered a space-time continuum.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Impossible to calculate. We lack data to analyse. Our  instruments appear to be functioning normally, but what they tell us  makes no sense. Our records are clear up to the point at which we left  our galaxy.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Unfortunately, we lack reference points on which to plot a  return course. We experienced extreme sensory distortion,  and we shall do so again if we attempt to use warp speed. And we cannot  re-cross the barrier using sub light speed.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: An entertaining suggestion, Mister Chekov, but not very helpful.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Very possibly. The Medusan sensory system is radically different  from ours. Perhaps for the purpose of this emergency I might become  Kollos.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: A fusion. A mind-link to create a double entity. Each of us  would enjoy the knowledge and sensory capabilities of both. We will  function as one being.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: If the link is successful there will be a tendency to lose  separate identity. A necessary risk. Of course, Doctor Jones will not  wish to give me permission to accomplish the mind-link.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Doctor Jones has shown reluctance every time I've asked to  converse with Kollos. In some ways, she is still most human, Captain,  particularly in the depth of her jealousy.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Not sufficient. Her telepathic powers are formidable. If it is  at all possible, her mind must be so engaged that no thought of what I  am doing shall intrude.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: The Enterprise is at stake. It is not possible for you to be  involved.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: This is not a duty that you can assume. I am aware of the fact  that your telepathic competence might be superior to mine, but there's  a more important factor. The object is to pilot this ship. That is  something you cannot do.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Evidently a highly sophisticated sensor web. My compliments to  you, and to your dressmaker.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: An elegant solution. but I fail to understand why you apparently  try to conceal your blindness, Doctor Jones.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: This is delightful. I know you. All of you. James Kirk, Captain  and friend for many years. And Leonard McCoy, also of long  acquaintance. And Uhura, whose name means freedom.   She walks in beauty, like the  night.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Are you surprised to find that I've read Byron, Doctor?

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: In part. That is, part of us is known to you as Kollos. Ah,  Miranda. There you are.   O brave new world, that has such creatures  in  it.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: My world is next for us. Captain Kirk, I speak for all of us you  call Medusans. I am sorry for the trouble I've brought to your ship.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: And now to the business at hand. With your permission, Captain.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Co-ordination is completed.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Warp one in six seconds. Five, four, three, two, one, zero.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Position report, please, Mister Chekov.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Thank you, Mister Chekov. Manoeuvre completed, Captain.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: How compact your bodies are. And what a variety of senses you  have. This thing you call language though, most remarkable. You depend  on it for so very much. But is any one of you really its master? But  most of all, the aloneness.  You are so alone. You live out your lives in this shell of flesh.  Self-contained, separate. How lonely you are. How terribly lonely.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: So soon?

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: You're a wise Captain.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: I rejoice in your knowledge and in your achievement.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: And the ways our differences combine to create meaning and  beauty.

title: Is  There In Truth No Beauty?
dialogue: Live long and prosper, Miranda.

title: The  Empath

dialogue: Negative, Captain. It doesn't register.

dialogue: Captain, picking up a life-form reading bearing four two mark  seven.

dialogue: Negative. Although humanoid, it is definitely not Homo Sapiens.
