dialogue: Impossible. I can make no exact identification other than it  being humanoid.

dialogue: Still undistinguishable.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: From what we know of the specific gravity and other  environmental factors of this planet, a life-form such as hers could  not evolve here.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: An unlikely possibility, Captain, since over ninety eight  percent of the known telepathic species send thoughts as well as  receive them. She's made no attempt to contact our minds.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Gem, Doctor?

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Correct, Captain.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Captain, in that direction, my tricorder is now picking up a  substantial collection of objects.

dialogue: Electronically sophisticated devices. I fail to understand why  my tricorder previously gave no indication of them being out there.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Readings indicate the passage to the surface lies in this  direction.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Research station six kilometres in that direction, Captain.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Just ahead.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: I believe they were never actually present, Doctor. It was a  mirage.

dialogue: Captain, it was a mirage.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Captain, I request permission to be allowed

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Doctor, I'm unable to lock in on the previous readings. I can  find no exit out of here.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Her withdrawal seemed to suggest the fear of death, Doctor. Only  your urging her on caused her to continue.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Can you recall what happened, Captain?

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Captain, I noted that a light preceded you at the moment you  were returned here from the Vian's laboratory.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: I conclude such a light is an energy transfer point linking this  device to the power source.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: If I can determine the frequency at which this device operates,  I might be able to cause it to function for us.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: I would say so.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: I do not know, Captain. I'm beginning to understand its  operating principles, but that is all.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Some men spend the majority of their lives in mines beneath the  surface.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: I've recorded my principles and theories on the tricorder,  Doctor. Should the Vians return, there is sufficient data for you and  the captain to complete the adjustments.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Possibly not, but you and the captain together will be able to  do so.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: How long will he be asleep, Doctor?

title: The  Empath
dialogue: I'm not criticizing your action, Doctor. On the contrary, I'm  quite grateful for it. The captain will be spared the strain of making  so difficult a decision. You have simplified the situation  considerably.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: While the captain is asleep, I am in command. When the Vians  return, I shall go with them.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Precisely. The choice would have been the captain's. Now it is  mine.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Your action is highly unethical. My decision stands.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: I was convinced in the same way you were, Captain. By the good  doctor's hypo.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Hmm. A most unusual device. It is a control unit, but not a  control mechanism. In fact, it is not a mechanical device.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: This control is attuned to one electrical pattern of energy, the  pattern produced by the mental impulses of the person who possesses it.  It is activated solely by mental commands.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: I shall attempt to do so. However, it is not possible to adjust  the control to fit more than one pattern at a time. I am, of course,  most familiar with my own pattern. Therefore, with your permission, I

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Fascinating. They must have known we were capable of  comprehending this control and making use of it.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: The only logical assumption is that they wish to let us go.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: That is evidently their intention, Captain.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Indeed, the facts would indicate that she's essential to their  purpose.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Completed, Captain. The adjustments are delicate. They may not  survive more than even one use. However, there should be sufficient  energy to transfer us to the Enterprise.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: If you so desire.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Severe heart damage. Signs of congestion in both lungs. Evidence  of massive circulatory collapse.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: He's dying, Jim. We can make him comfortable, but that is all.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Internal injuries. Bleeding in the chest and abdomen.  Haemorrhage of the spleen and liver. Seventy percent kidney failure.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: It could happen anytime.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: I'm afraid not.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Uncertain, Captain. Dr. McCoy's analysis of her reaction assumes  that her instinct for self-preservation would prevent it. However, we  cannot be positive.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: What purpose can be served by the death of our friend, except to  bring you pleasure? Surely beings as advanced as yourselves know that  your star system will soon be extinct. Your sun will nova.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Then you also know that the millions of inhabitants on its  planets are doomed.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: You were correct, Captain. Everything that has occurred here has  been caused to happen by them. This has all been a great laboratory,  and we have been the subjects of the test.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Captain, Dr. McCoy's life is not solely dependent on Gem. The  Vians too must be capable of saving his life.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Captain?

title: The  Empath
dialogue: The intensity of emotion is draining us and building up the  force field.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: It draws its energy from us, Captain. In spite of what we see,  all emotion must be suppressed. That might weaken the field.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: It is complete. Gem has earned the right of survival for her  planet. She offered her life.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: What is puzzling you, Captain?

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Captain, the element of chance can virtually be eliminated by a  civilisation as advanced as the Vians.

title: The  Empath
dialogue: Possibly, Captain. I shall certainly give the thought all the  consideration it is due.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Captain, we are registering very curious readings from all  sensors.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: I cannot. According to our instruments, space itself is  literally breaking up. There is no known phenomenon which would account  for these readings.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Negative. I have run a complete check on all systems.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: There is virtually no sensor contact. No mass analysis. No trace  of radiation. We see it, but our sensors indicate it is not there.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Absolutely no record of such an occurrence, Ensign.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: The ship is still functioning, Captain. It is logical to assume  the mutineers are somewhere aboard.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Captain, there is no sign of life aboard this vessel.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Captain, the Defiant's sensors correspond  with an extremely high degree of correlation to those of the  Enterprise.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Affirmative.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Request permission to remain, Captain. I could be completing the  data.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Captain, there is a chance

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Energise.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Negative.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Compute the next period of spatial interphase.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: We must try, Mister Scott. The fabric of space is very weak  here. If we disturb it, there will be no chance of retrieving the  Captain alive.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Well, picture it this way, Mister Chekov. We exist in a universe  which co-exists with a multitude of others in the same physical space.  At certain brief periods of time, an area of their space overlaps an  area of ours. That is a time of interphase, during which we can connect  with the Defiant's universe.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Yes. However, the dimensional structure of each universe is  totally dissimilar. Any use of power disturbs it. If we are not  extremely careful, we shall lose the Captain and become trapped  ourselves.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Chekov! Chekov!

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Security guards to the Bridge.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: I was attempting to explain to Mister Chekov the nature of our  problems in this situation when he attacked.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Lieutenant Uhura is correct. There was murderous fury in Chekov.  The same fury which was evident in the Defiant.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Is there anything you need to isolate the cause?

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: If we are to recover the Captain, we must not move.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Approximately two hours before the attempt can be made.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: The Captain was caught in our transporter beam when the Defiant  phased out. It is possible he was spared the shock of transition and  survived. However, if we are to recover him, we must catch him at the  precise moment during the next interphase, or he will die. And there  can be no margin for error. His environmental unit can provide  breathable air for no more than three point six two hours.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Status, Mister Sulu.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Lieutenant Uhura, signal Red Alert.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Transfer to main viewer.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Spock, in command of the Federation star ship Enterprise.  Commander, according to the Federation, this area is free space.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: We are not interested in your display of force. The Enterprise  is responding to a distress signal from one of our ships and is  currently engaged in rescue operations. Do you wish to assist us?

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: The other ship is interspatially trapped. It should reappear in  one hour and fifty three minutes. We request you stand by until then.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: I shall have to recalculate to determine  when the next interphase will occur. They do not take place at regular  intervals.

title: The  Tholian Web

title: The  Tholian Web

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: The decision to fight was logical. Lack of time prevented any  other course of action. The Tholian ship had to be disabled.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Doctor, I hardly believe this is the time for comparisons.  Please go to your laboratory and search for an antidote to the effects  of this space. That is your primary task, since we must remain here.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Negative. Lieutenant Uhura, can you open a channel to the  approaching vessel?

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Distance, Mister Sulu.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Mister Sulu, I shall run an analysis on those filaments. Tie in  all sensors to the ship's library computer console.  Switch scanners.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: There's no analogy to this structure in Federation technology.  It is, however, an energy field, and if the Tholians are successful in  completing this structure before we have completed our repairs, we  shall not see home again.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Doctor, your last report on an antidote on the effects of this  space was negative.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: The urgency requires your personal attention in the laboratory.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: A few hours ago, the Captain elected to remain on board the  Defiant so that three members of this crew would have the best chance  of returning safely to the Enterprise. His concern was not only for  them, but for all the members of the crew of this ship. You all know  the sequence of events. We were fired upon by the Tholian ship. At that  time, Captain Kirk may have been alive. I deemed it necessary to return  the Tholian fire for the safety of the Enterprise. The Tholian ship has  been disabled. But as a result of the battle, we must accept the fact  that Captain Kirk is no longer alive.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: I shall not attempt to voice the quality of respect and  admiration which Captain Kirk commanded. Each of you must evaluate the  loss in the privacy of your own thoughts.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: It can wait, Doctor. My duties require my immediate presence on  the bridge.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: It will wait for a more suitable moment, Doctor.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: The mental and physical state of this crew are your  responsibility, Doctor. At the moment, they are your top priority.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: We came here for a specific purpose, Doctor.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: The Captain would have remained to recover a crew member at the  risk of his own life or even his own ship.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: I need not explain my rationale to you or any other member of  this crew. There is a margin of variation in any experiment. While  there was a chance, I was bound legally and morally to ascertain the  Captain's status.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: That is enough, Doctor. We both have other things to do.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: You will return to your duty as soon as we've discharged our  responsibilities here.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Doctor, I am in command of the Enterprise.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: If you believe I have acted irregularly, then relieve me of  duty. That is your prerogative as medical officer of this ship.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: What would you have me say, Doctor?

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Spock here.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: I shall be there shortly. Doctor, I believe we each have our  respective tasks to complete before the Tholians complete theirs.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Spock here. Proceed, Mister Scott.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Report to Doctor McCoy all symptoms noted  prior to the attack.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Negative. We are relatively stable at the  moment.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Mister Scott?

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Report to the bridge immediately.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: In critical moments, men sometimes see exactly what they wish to  see.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: I was merely stating a fact, Doctor.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Please leave that to me, Doctor McCoy. I realise that the crew  are your prime concern. You can best serve them in your laboratory. I  urge you to confine yourself to it until a remedy has been found.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: I understand, Doctor. I'm sure the Captain would simply have  said forget it, Bones.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Captain? Captain? Captain.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Exactly. But the Captain remained. Only the overlap time  changed. The next interphase will occur here.

dialogue: Can you be ready?

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: It will have to do, Mister Scott.  Come.

dialogue: You've found the antidote, Doctor.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Ensign Chekov was affected so early. Has he responded to it?

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Theragen? A nerve gas used by the Klingons.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: If I remember correctly, it caused fatality only when used in  pure form.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Welcome back, Lieutenant.

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: Your absence was keenly felt, Mister Chekov.

title: The  Tholian Web

title: The  Tholian Web
dialogue: We shall soon see, Lieutenant.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: An asteroid, two hundred miles in diameter.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Negative, Captain. We've had that area on scanners constantly.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Correct, Captain.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Typical asteroid chemically, but it is not orbiting. It is  pursing an independent course through this solar system.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: It is under power, Captain. And correcting for all gravitational  stresses.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Atomic. Very archaic. Leaving a trail of debris and hard  radiation.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Asteroid has an outer shell, which is hollow. It surrounds an  independent inner core, which has a breathable atmosphere. Sensors read  no life forms.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Then the passengers, or builders, are dead.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Interesting.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: The course Ensign Chekov just gave for the asteroid would put it  on a collision course with Daran Five.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Correct. Population approximately three billion and seven  hundred twenty four million, if memory serves me correctly. Estimated  time of impact three hundred ninety six days.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: One fails to see the logic in making a ship look like a planet.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: The asteroid ship is over ten thousand years old, Doctor. Still  no sign of life forms, Captain.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: The doctor must have received an excessively large electrical  shock.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Nothing else could've caused this, Captain. At least nothing  that has happened here.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: May I ask precisely what is troubling the doctor?

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Yes. I know of it, Captain.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Very well, Doctor. The Captain and I seem to have suffered no  ill effects.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Captain, informing these people they're on a ship may be in  violation of the Prime Directive of Starfleet Command.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Logical, Captain.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Also logical, Captain.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: He said it was forbidden to climb the mountains.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Indeed, Doctor. The young lady did show a marked preference for  your company.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: We are very interested in your world.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Incredible as it may seem, these people have  no idea they're living on a spaceship.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Captain, the Oracle room.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: I believe that I can.  The  writing is definitely Fabrini, Captain. I recognise it.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Yes. Towards the end, the Fabrini people lived underground, as  these people do, to protect themselves.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Captain. If I remember correctly, the oracle's reprehensible  conduct was initiated when Natira knelt on that platform.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Nothing here which would indicate this is anything but a planet.  There's no question but that the creators would be considered gods.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Eight planets, Captain. That is the number in the Fabrina solar  system.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: And no doubt they've been in flight on this asteroid ship for  ten thousand years.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Your decision is most illogical, Doctor.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: I believe it's time to move on.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Temperature one hundred eleven degrees and rising.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Temperature one hundred fifteen degrees.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: One hundred twenty degrees.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: I've neutralised the heating elements.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: There seems to be a weakness in one of the eight tubes.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Yes. Let me check that engine. A very simple problem, easy to  correct.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: I believe we can attempt the course  correction, Captain.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Guidance control's taking over. I believe we can allow this ship  to go back to its automatic control.

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky

title: For  The World Is Hollow And I Have Touched The Sky
dialogue: Your haemoglobin count is back to normal, Doctor, which  indicates that the flow of oxygen to each cell of your body is back up  to its abundantly energetic level.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Sensors have picked up a Klingon ship,  closing fast.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: And we never fired upon her.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Understood, Captain. Transporter room.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Our landing party is intact, Doctor.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: First group from the Klingon vessel, Captain.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: At the moment we received the distress signal from the colony on  Beta Twelve A, the Klingons were too far distant to have been the  attackers. Moreover, they also were apparently attracted by a distress  call.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Our log tapes will indicate our innocence in the present  situation.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Sensor sweeps reveal no other ships within range, Captain.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Captain, neither the Klingon technology nor ours, is capable of  this. The instantaneous transmutation of matter. I doubt that they are  responsible.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: None. However, if they had such power, would they not have used  it to create more effective weapons and only for themselves?

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Scans indicate that our forces and those of the Klingons are  exactly equal at thirty eight each. The Klingons control deck six and  starboard deck seven, while we control all sections above.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Most curious, Captain. There appear to be more life-energy units  on board than can be accounted for by the presence of the Enterprise  crew plus the Klingons. A considerable discrepancy.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: I shall attempt a compensatory reading of Klingon units.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: No additional Klingons detected, Captain. It  is an alien life force, a single entity. I cannot ascertain its  location.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Readings being diverted to the library computer for analysis.  Computer report.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: What purpose?

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: If the alien is creating these events, Captain, it is apparently  capable of manipulating matter and mind.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Captain, I am constrained to point out that since minds are  evidently being influenced, we cannot know at this moment whether our  own memories are completely accurate and true.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: An appropriate choice of terms. However, it is notoriously  difficult to arrange a truce with the Klingons once blood has been  drawn.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: We are attempting to end it, Doctor. By reason, preferably.  There is an alien on board which may have created this situation.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Easy, Mister Scott.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: May I say that I have not thoroughly enjoyed serving with  humans? I find their illogic and foolish emotions a constant irritant.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Fascinating. The result of stress?

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Recent events would seem to be directed toward a magnification  of the basic hostilities between humans and Klingons. Apparently, it is  by design that we fight. We seem to be pawns.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: It is most urgent that we locate the alien entity immediately,  and determine its motives and a method for halting its activities.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Sensors may be operating.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Alien detected in the engineering section,  near reactor number three.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Jim, he's not responsible.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: It would appear that the entity wants us alive.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Perhaps human and Klingon psychologies and combat capabilities  are being tested by an alien with designs on both powers.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: I understand, Doctor. I, too, felt a brief surge of racial  bigotry. Most distasteful.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Totally unfamiliar.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Fascinating. During Lieutenant Johnson's emotional outburst, his  expression of hatred and lust for vengeance, the alien's life energy  level increased. When the Lieutenant became unconscious, the alien lost  energy.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: This one appears to be strengthened by mental irradiations of  hostility, violent intentions.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: To put it simply. And it has acted as a catalyst, creating this  situation in order to satisfy that need. It has brought together  opposing forces, provided crude instruments in an effort to promote the  most violent mode of conflict.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Then all hostile attitudes on board must be eliminated. The  fighting must end and soon.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: The alien is affecting his mind, Captain. Soon, it will become  so powerful that none of us will be able to resist it.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: There's nothing we can do about it.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: We have nine minutes, fifty three seconds to power zero.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: There is, of course, a logical alternative. Kang's wife is, after all,  our prisoner. Perhaps a threat.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Eight minutes, forty two seconds.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: It has rarely been done because of the danger involved. Pinpoint  accuracy is required. If the transportee should materialise inside a  solid object, a deck or wall.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: No one can guarantee the actions of another.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: When transporter is energised, you will have  eight seconds to get to the pads.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: Those who hate and fight must stop themselves, Doctor.  Otherwise, it is not stopped.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: All fighting must end, Captain, to weaken the alien before our  dilithium crystals are gone.

title: The  Day Of The Dove
dialogue: The cessation of violence appears to have weakened it, Captain.  I suggest that good spirits might make an effective weapon.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: How is the power transmitted?

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Do these waves cease while you are asleep?

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Thirty five.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Fascinating. I believe we're experiencing the psychokinetic  manifestations of Parmen's delirium.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: How does one obtain the power?

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Captain, it will be very gratifying to leave here.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Even if he shouldn't.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Doctor McCoy, you may yet cure the common cold.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Obviously Parmen does not wish any contact made with the  Enterprise.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: To shut out any knowledge of his brutal treatment of a Starfleet  captain.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Agreed, Captain. And Parmen wouldn't have treated you so  brutally if he had any intention of releasing you or the Enterprise.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Whose harmony? Yours? Plato wanted truth and beauty, and above  all, justice.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Two spacemen marching to a drum.   KIRK +

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: We slith among the mimsey toves, and gyre among the  borogoves.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: I trust they did not injure you too much, Captain.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: The humiliation must have been most difficult for you to bear. I  can understand.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: That may be, Doctor. However, I have noted that the healthy  release of emotion is frequently very unhealthy for those closest to  you.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: So it would seem. Captain.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Do you still feel anger toward Parmen?

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: And you, Doctor?

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Then you must release it, gentlemen, as I must master mine. I  might have seriously injured you, Captain, even killed you. They have  evoked such great hatred in me, I cannot allow it to go further. I must  master it. I must control.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Alexander, it is possible for you to recall how long after you  arrived here that that power began to develop?

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: And would you know how many months' supplies you brought with  you?

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: That's close enough, Alexander. Fascinating. Their power  developed two or three months after they started eating the native  foods.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Then it is logical to assume that there is a connection between  the psychokinetic power and the eating of the native foods.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Perhaps his system cannot absorb the crucial element.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: The probabilities are that Alexander was born with some  biochemical deficiency relative to Platonius.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: The pituitary hormones confirm the hypothesis. They also  regulate body growth.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Yes. It's also obvious why Parmen kept this little utopia  secret. Anyone coming down here and remaining long enough would acquire  the power.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: The point is well taken. However, the psychokinetic power is not  additive. If it were, considering the Platonians' hostile propensities,  two or three of them would have combined forces centuries ago and  deposed Parmen.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: The time factor concerns me. It may take days or even weeks  before there's enough build up from the kironide to be of any benefit  to us.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: I have experienced a slight flush, Captain.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Take care, young ladies, and value your wine. Be  watchful of young men in their velvet prime.   Deeply they'll swallow from your finest kegs. Then swiftly be gone  leaving bitter dregs. Ah, bitter dregs.   With smiling words and tender touch. Man offers little and asks for so  much"   He loves in the breathless excitement of night, then leaves with your  treasure in cold morning light. Ah, in cold morning light"

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: We have tried.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: I haven't the power. I'm deeply sorry. We've failed you.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: Quite possible and logical.

title: Plato's  Stepchildren
dialogue: That would be highly uncharacteristic. We must expect, Parmen,  that the moment we leave here, your fear would be gone and you would  again be as sadistic and as arrogant as your twenty five hundred years  have made you.

title: Wink  Of An Eye
dialogue: Evidently a civilisation of high order, rating number seven on  the industrial scale. Humanoid in appearance, according to the  paintings. An abundance of literature, which I shall have translated  and processed. Certain structures hold evidence of recent occupancy  while others are apparently long abandoned.

title: Wink  Of An Eye
dialogue: Instrument readings indicate life-form, but of a highly unusual  and intermittent nature. They have no discernible form or location. A  most puzzling phenomenon, Captain. I shall have to study it further.

title: Wink  Of An Eye
dialogue: Unknown at present, Captain.

title: Wink  Of An Eye
dialogue: It is logical to assume that this distress call was  pre-recorded. What we received was evidently a delayed taped message.

title: Wink  Of An Eye
dialogue: It would seem that some force or agent only partially  discernible to our instruments may have been responsible.

title: Wink  Of An Eye
dialogue: I have a reading from Life Support centre. Alien substances  being introduced.

title: Wink  Of An Eye
dialogue: It is a force field, Captain, the nature of which I'm not  familiar with. I'm getting readings of an alien presence similar to  those obtained on the planet's surface, but they seem to have no exact  location.

title: Wink  Of An Eye

title: Wink  Of An Eye

title: Wink  Of An Eye

title: Wink  Of An Eye

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: I suggest no supernatural explanation, Captain. I merely point  out that the facts do not fit any known categories of planets.

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: It would be impossible, Captain. An atmosphere could not evolve  in so short a period of time.

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Precisely, Captain.

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Give me a full report as soon as possible,  please. Spock out. Mister Scott, have the transporter checked for  possible malfunction.

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Mister Scott, since we are here, your statement is not only  illogical but also unworthy of refutation. It is also illogical to  assume that any explosion, even that of a small star going supernova,  could have hurled us a distance of nine hundred and ninety point seven  light years.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: That is correct, Mister Scott, by all the laws that we know.  There was no period of unconsciousness. Our ship's chronometers  registered a matter of only a few seconds. Therefore, we were displaced  through space in some manner which I am unable to fathom.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Please, Mister Scott, restrain your leaps of illogic. I have  said nothing. I was merely speculating.   M'BENGA : Sickbay to Mister Spock.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Spock here.    M'BENGA: You asked for an autopsy report. It's only  preliminary, but the cause of death seems to have been cellular  disruption.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Explain.    M'BENGA: It's as though every cell in the body had  been individually blasted from inside.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Would any known disease organism do that?    M'BENGA: Doctor Sanchez has ruled that possibility  out, sir.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Please keep me fully advised. Spock out. He  was in the transporter room. Someone may have entered after Captain  Kirk and his party left. Mister Scott, since the Enterprise is  obviously functional, I suggest we return to our starting place at top  warp speed.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: In that case, Mister Scott, I suggest we start at once. Can you  give me warp eight?

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: That position, Mister Scott, would not only be unavailing but  also undignified. Lieutenant Rahda, plot a course.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Good. Then prepare to come to warp eight.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Eleven point three three seven hours, Lieutenant. I wish you  would be more precise.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Spock here.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Feels, Mister Scott?

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: That is obvious, Mister Scott. I suggest you avoid emotionalism  and simply keep your instruments correct.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Spock here.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Do you know what he died of, Mister Scott?

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Security alert, all decks. Female intruder, extremely dangerous.  Security alert. All decks.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Spock to Sickbay. Have you completed the  autopsy on Watkins, Doctor?   M'BENGA : Yes, we have, Mister Spock.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: Was the cause of his death the same as that which killed the  transporter officer?    M'BENGA: Well, the pattern of cellular disruption  was the same, but as to the cause, well your guess is as good as mine.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: My guess, Doctor, would be valueless. I  suggest we refrain from guessing and find some facts.

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: The power of this intruder to disrupt every  cell in a body, combined with the almost inconceivable power required  to hurl the Enterprise such a distance, speak of a very high culture  and a very great danger.

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: If there are more of those beings on that planet, the captain  and the others are in very great danger.

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives
dialogue: No, but the method is fascinating.

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: That  Which Survives

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Captain, there is one living creature aboard. Humanoid. He is  either injured or ill. His craft shows internal atmospheric leakage.  The creature may be suffocating.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: There is no theory, Captain, from the basic work of Mendel to  recent nucleotide studies, which would explain our captive. All  gradations of colour from black to brown, to yellow to white are  genetically predictable. We must therefore conclude that this alien is  that often unaccountable rarity, a mutation, one of a kind.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Yet you are pumping him full of your noxious potions as if he  were a human.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: We do not know that Lokai has done that.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: The obvious visual evidence, Commissioner, is that he is of the  same breed as yourself.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Commissioner, perhaps the experience of my own planet Vulcan may  set an example of some value to you. Vulcan was in danger of being  destroyed by the same conditions and characteristics which threaten to  destroy Cheron. We were once a people like yourselves, wildly  emotional, often committed to irrationally opposing points of view,  leading, of course, to death and destruction. Only the discipline of  logic saved my planet from extinction.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Change is the essential process of all existence. For instance,  the people of Cheron must have once been mono-coloured.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: The actual theory is that all life-forms evolved from the lower  levels to the more advanced stages.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Trouble, Mister Chekov?

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Captain, some of the memory banks of the computer are burned  out.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: I doubt that the same can be said for many of his followers.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Captain, we are within scanning range of Cheron.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Coming within visual range now, Captain.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Several large cities, uninhabited. Extensive traffic systems,  barren of traffic. Lower animal sand vegetation encroaching on the  cities. No sapient life-forms registering at all, Captain. There is no  evidence of natural disaster, yet there are vast numbers of unburied  corpses in all cities.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: All dead, Captain. They have annihilated each other totally.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: None at all, sir.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield
dialogue: Negative, Captain. Transporter room is clear. However, there is  a life-form materialising on the planet. It is Lokai. He is back on  Cheron.

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield

title: Let  That Be Your Last Battlefield

title: Whom  Gods Destroy

title: Whom  Gods Destroy

title: Whom  Gods Destroy

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: Very well indeed, thank you, Captain.

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: If you could create a diversion, I might be able to  find the control room and open the force field.

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: I find it mildly interesting and somewhat nostalgic, if I  understand the use of that word.

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: Yes. It is somewhat reminiscent of the dances that Vulcan  children do in nursery school. Of course, the children are not so well  co-ordinated.

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: On what, precisely, is our friendship to be based?

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: Why?

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: How could you, a Starship fleet Captain, believe that a  Federation crew would blindly obey your order to destroy the entire  Antos race, a people famous for their benevolence and peaceful  pursuits?

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: Captain Kirk speaks somewhat figuratively and with undue  emotion. However, what he says is logical and I do, in fact, agree with  it.

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: Please forgive me, but exactly where is your fleet?

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: Captain Garth

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: As you wish. At any rate, you must be aware of the fact that you  are attempting to recreate the disaster which resulted in your becoming  an inmate in this place.

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: On the contrary. You were treated with justice, and with  compassion which you failed to show towards any of your intended  victims. Logically, therefore, one must assume

title: Whom  Gods Destroy
dialogue: Thank you, Captain.  We're now armed. I presume  we shall try to reach the control room.

title: Whom  Gods Destroy

Failing a resolution to the struggle, I was forced  to use other means to make my determination.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon

dialogue: Your Excellency, I am basically a scientist.  Clarity of formulation is essential in my profession also.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Yes, Your Excellency.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon

title: The  Mark Of Gideon

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Your Excellency, your assistant has arrived  safely, and I am now ready to transport down to Gideon.

dialogue: Sir, our captain is still missing, and I now demand that I be  allowed to transport to Gideon as we agreed.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Do not give up hope. Lieutenant Uhura, contact Starfleet  Command. Demand an immediate reply to our request for permission to  beam down to Gideon.

dialogue: Admiral, the crew will not understand it.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: We wish only to save the life of the captain.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: I am positive that I can do so to your satisfaction, Admiral. I  have been convinced, since my first exchange with the ambassador, that  the captain has been taken prisoner.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: I now know where the captain is being held, if he is being held  at the same place to which we transported him.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Sir, the captain is not being held in the Gideon council  chamber. He is being held nearby.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Since the planet is shielded from our sensors, we cannot  establish that without on the spot investigation.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Admiral, I wish to state for the record that your decision is  completely arbitrary.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: They did not ask for our understanding, Doctor.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Unfortunately, I must violate a direct order from Starfleet.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: I do not make it lightly, Doctor. However, Command knows that  Ambassador Hodin has not been totally honest with us. Lieutenant Uhura,  repeat original Gideon co-ordinates for beam down.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Mister Scott, the co-ordinates given you?

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Precisely. I shall beam down at once. Mister Scott, you have the  conn.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Negative, Doctor. I cannot accept the responsibility for  ordering a fellow officer to violate a Starfleet directive. I can make  such a decision only for myself.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: The situation forces me to do so, Doctor.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: This will not take long.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Captain Kirk. Spock here.  Captain Kirk?

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: An exact duplicate of the Enterprise. But  completely inoperative.  Spock to Enterprise. Spock  to Enterprise.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: I am speaking to you from the bridge of the Enterprise.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: And they were correct. I'm on board an exact  duplicate of the Enterprise.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: In orbit, Doctor. In a manner of speaking,  Gideon is in orbit and the ship is on Gideon.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: I'm sure he's on board somewhere. I'm  picking up life readings. Spock out.   Ship's log, stardate 5423.8. First Officer Spock  reporting. Obviously the Gideon's have transported Captain Kirk onto  this replica of the Enterprise to so confuse his mind as to make him  susceptible to some extraordinary experiment. It is my intention to  locate the captain and warn him before the experiment reaches its  conclusion, which logic indicates means the end of the captain's life  as he knows it.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Your Excellency. Captain, you're looking well. Evidently  Starfleet's analysis was correct.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon
dialogue: Spock to Enterprise. Spock to Enterprise.

title: The  Mark Of Gideon

title: The  Lights Of Zetar

title: The  Lights Of Zetar

title: The  Lights Of Zetar

title: The  Lights Of Zetar

title: The  Lights Of Zetar
dialogue: Doctor McCoy is correct, Captain. There is an identity of minds  taking place  between the alien beings and the mind of Lieutenant Romaine. Their  thoughts are becoming hers.

title: The  Lights Of Zetar

title: The  Lights Of Zetar

title: The  Cloud Minders

title: The  Cloud Minders
dialogue: Stratos, Captain. A city actually floating in the sky.

title: The  Cloud Minders
dialogue: It is one of the most interesting metropolises in the galaxy.  Have you ever visited here, Captain?

title: The  Cloud Minders
dialogue: I've never had the opportunity. However, I hear its art forms  are incomparable.

title: The  Cloud Minders
dialogue: It is a totally intellectual society. All forms of violence have  been eliminated.

title: The  Cloud Minders

title: The  Cloud Minders

title: The  Cloud Minders
dialogue: But they are not allowed to share its advantages.

title: The  Cloud Minders
dialogue: The surface of the planet is almost unendurable. To restrict a  segment of the population to such hardship is unthinkable in an evolved  culture.

title: The  Cloud Minders

title: The  Cloud Minders

title: The  Cloud Minders

title: The  Cloud Minders
dialogue: But they're all the same species. Those who live on Stratos and  those who live below all originated on the planet. Their physical and  mental evolution must be similar. That is basic biological law.

title: The  Cloud Minders

dialogue: As part of the staff of Stratos, Vanna was removed from exposure  for a long period. It is likely that without such exposure, the effect  slowly wears off.

title: The  Cloud Minders
dialogue: Unequal evolution did not begin until after your ancestors  removed themselves from constant exposure to the gas, Mister Advisor.

title: The  Cloud Minders

title: The  Way To Eden

title: The  Way To Eden
dialogue: There are many who are uncomfortable with what we have created.  It is almost a biological rebellion. A profound revulsion against the  planned communities, the programming, the sterilised, artfully balanced  atmospheres. They hunger for an Eden where spring comes.

title: The  Way To Eden
dialogue: Yes, that is true, Captain.

title: The  Way To Eden
dialogue: It is not sympathy so much as curiosity, Captain. A wish to  understand. They regard themselves as aliens in their own worlds, a  condition with which I am somewhat familiar.

title: The  Way To Eden
dialogue: It is somewhat uncomplimentary, Captain. Herbert was a minor  official notorious for his rigid and limited patterns of thought.

title: The  Way To Eden
dialogue: I shall make an attempt, Captain.

title: The  Way To Eden
dialogue: Yes, sir.   Captain's log, stardate 5832.5. The arrogance of  Doctor Sevrin and his followers is creating an intolerable situation  aboard the Enterprise. If it continues, I'll be forced to use controls  which might not agree with Starfleet's suggestion that they be handled  with extreme tolerance.

title: The  Way To Eden
dialogue: They respect you. They will listen to your reasoning. For their  sake, you must stop them. Doctor Sevrin, I'm in a position to help you  and your group. I can use the resources of the Enterprise to determine  whether or not Eden actually exists and to plot its exact location. I  can present a case to Federation to allow you and your group to  colonise that planet. Neither you nor your people are at present  charged with a crime. However, incitement to disaffection is criminal.  The Federation will never allow the colonisation of a planet by  criminals. If they persist, they will be so charged and forever barred  from Eden.

title: The  Way To Eden

title: The  Way To Eden
