title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Strange. Readings indicate a life form in the vicinity,  apparently human. Yet ship's sensors indicated this planet was  uninhabited.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Did you say your planet, sir?

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Mister Flint, unless you are certain, I would suggest you  refrain from a most useless experiment.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Are you a student of history, sir?

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Then you live here alone.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: It would seem logical to do so for the moment.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: This is the most splendid private collection of art I've ever  seen, and the most unique. The majority are the works of Leonardo da  Vinci, Renaissance period, some of the works of Reginald Pollack, 20th  century, and even a sten from Marcus Two.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Thank you, Doctor. I will have a brandy.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: If I appear distracted, it is because of what I have seen. I am  close to experiencing an unaccustomed emotion.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Envy. None of these da Vinci paintings has ever been catalogued  or reproduced. They are unknown works, all apparently authentic to the  last brush stroke and use of materials. As undiscovered da Vinci's,  they would be priceless.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Most strange. A man of Flint's obvious wealth and impeccable  taste scarcely needs to hang fakes. Yet my tricorder analysis indicates  that the canvas and pigments used are of contemporary origin.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Indeed. I would appreciate such a talk. It is an interest of  mine.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Irillium will render the antitoxin inert and useless.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Captain. Something else which is rather extraordinary. This  waltz I just played is by Johannes Brahms.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Captain, it is written in manuscript. In original manuscript, in  Brahms' own hand, which I recognise. It is totally unknown, definitely  the work of Brahms, and yet unknown.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Fortunately, the robot did not detect my presence and deactivate  my phaser.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Since we are dependent on Mister Flint for the ryetalyn,  Captain, may I respectfully suggest that you pay less attention to the  young lady if you should encounter her again. Our host's interests do  not appear to be confined to art and science.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Strongly indicated.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: It does appear to defy the male logic as I understand it.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: We have still a greater mystery, Captain. I was able to run a  tricorder scan on Mister Flint. He is human, but there are certain  biophysical peculiarities. Some body function readings are  disproportionate. For one thing, extreme age is indicated on the order  of six thousand years.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: I shall programme the readings through Doctor McCoy's medical  computer when we return to the ship.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: We must commence ryetalyn injections within two hours and  eighteen minutes or the epidemic will prove fatal to us all.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Captain, I would suggest that our immediate concern is the  ryetalyn.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Interesting. Obviously, Mister Flint is not yet ready for us to  depart.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: The captain wanted us to wait here.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Picking up tricorder readings, Captain. Apparently the ryetalyn  is behind this door.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Captain, I shall get the ryetalyn.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: There may be dangers within.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Let me go alone, Captain.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Your collection of Leonardo da Vinci masterpieces, Mister Flint,  they appear to have been recently painted  on contemporary canvas with contemporary materials. And on your piano,  a waltz by Johannes Brahms, an unknown work in manuscript, written in  modern ink. Yet absolutely authentic, as are your paintings.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: And da Vinci?

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: How many other names shall we call you?

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: You were born?

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Your wealth and your intellect are the product of centuries of  acquisition. You knew the greatest minds in history.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: You wanted a perfect, ultimate woman, as brilliant, as immortal  as yourself. Your mate for all time.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: I had hoped I was wrong.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: We have discovered what he is, Captain.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: We can remain silent.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: What will you feel for him after we are gone?

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Captain, your primitive impulses will not alter the  circumstances.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: No, you're not, for she is not.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Gentlemen, I urge you to stop. There is a danger.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: She loved you, Captain. And you, too, Mister Flint, as a mentor,  even as a father. There was not enough time for her to adjust to the  awful power and contradictions of her new-found emotions. She could not  bear to hurt either of you.  The joys of love made her human, and the agonies of love destroyed her.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: The epidemic is reduced and no longer a threat. The Enterprise  is on course five one three mark seven, as you ordered.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Your report, Doctor.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: On that day, I shall mourn. Does he know?

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Indeed.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Goodnight, Doctor.

title: Requiem  For Methuselah
dialogue: Forget.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: I still read a suggestion of carbon cycle life forms on the  planet surface, Captain.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Agreed. Mister Sulu, switch to the planet area I have under  observation.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Which would indicate a considerable civilisation there.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Our readings could be false, Captain, perhaps caused by some  natural phenomena.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: We're being scanned, Captain. A deep probe, incredibly swift.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Fascinating.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: They did scan us and our vessel, Captain, and doubtless obtained  sufficient information to present this illusion.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Small change occurring there, Captain.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: An area of approximately one thousand square kilometres. It  measures completely Earth-like.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Fascinating. For a moment, it appeared almost mineral. Like  living rock with heavy fore claws. It's settling down now to completely  human readings.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Band honours ready, Captain.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: We do, sir. Six hundred forty three miles, two thousand twenty  one feet, two point zero four inches at this moment, using your  old-style measurements.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: It is basic to the Vulcan philosophy, sir. The combination of a  number of things to make existence worthwhile.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: More that direction, Engineer.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: I am, Doctor. I am observing the alien.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: It would be illogical. With such abilities, they could as easily  trick us into destroying the entire vessel.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: No, I'm not, Doctor. There's no doubt they want us down there  for some hidden purpose. Otherwise, they would have revealed some  logical reason for all of this.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Speculation is unnecessary, Captain. The answer is clear.  President Lincoln has always been a very personal hero to you. What  better way to titillate your curiosity than to make him come alive for  you.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Agreed. I, too, experienced his charm. It is a magnificent work  of duplication.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Captain, since I was included in the invitation to make contact,  I must beam down with you.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Captain. Our phasers and tricorders did not beam down with us.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Undamaged, yet something is preventing them from functioning.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Surak.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: The greatest of all who ever lived on our planet, Captain. The  father of all we became.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: It is not logical that you are Surak. There is no fact,  extrapolation of fact or theory, which would make possible.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Live long and prosper, image of Surak, father of all we now hold  true.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: As I turned and my eyes beheld you, I displayed emotion. I beg  forgiveness.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: It may be exactly as explained, Captain. Our concept of good and  evil is strange to them. Perhaps they wish to determine which is  strongest.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: I'm all right, Captain. However, I suggest that we prepare  ourselves for another attack.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: And if they're real, Captain?

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Yes, Captain.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Captain. Logic dictates that we consider another course.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: His convictions are most profound in this matter, Captain.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: The captain knows that I have fought at his side before and will  do so now, if need be. However, I too, am a Vulcan, bred to peace. Let  him attempt it.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: I deeply respect what he has accomplished.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: They're trying to goad us into attacking, Captain. They expect  us to act rashly.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: He was aware of what might happen when he went.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: You had no choice, Captain. You could not have stopped him.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: A Vulcan would not cry out so.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: I am not insensitive to it, Captain.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Captain, that is what they are waiting for. They're waiting for  us to attempt a rescue.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: No, sir.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Conjecture, Captain, rather than explanation.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: It would seem that we were held in the power of creatures able  to control matter and to rearrange molecules in whatever fashion was  desired. So they were able to create images of Surak and Lincoln after  scanning our minds and using their fellow creatures as source matter.

title: The  Savage Curtain
dialogue: Yes, and Surak. Perhaps in a sense they were real, Captain.  Since they were created out of our own thoughts, how could they be  anything but what we expected them to be?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: The power source we detected is in this building, Captain.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: No signs of sapient life forms.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Reports deny that they had any space flight capability. This  appears to be an archive or library of some kind.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Forgive me, sir. It is my fault. I must have miscalculated. Our  readings indicated that there was no one here at all.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Three hours, thirteen minutes.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Exactly what is it that I'm expected to select?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: I see. This is a fascinating machine. What is it?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Interesting nomenclature. How does it work? May I

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Thank you, Mister Atoz.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Yes, and where is the captain?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Heating this boulder may provide some  temporary heat.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Something's preventing my phaser from operating.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Captain, we hear you, but we cannot see you.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Apparently they've all escaped the  destruction of their world by retreating into its past.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Indeed not. We're in a wilderness of arctic characteristics.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: There is no library, Captain, at least not  that we can see. We are at the base of an ice cliff.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Just before you disappeared, Captain, I  discovered a machine which Mister Atoz called the atavachron.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Opening time portals to the past. You cross  through into the period which you were viewing.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: I am here, evidently, because I stepped through at the same  instant as Doctor McCoy.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: We may be in trouble ourselves. We must find shelter.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: In this severe cold, we cannot survive much longer.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: We go together or not at all.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: We go together.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: He's suffering from the severity of your weather. Unfortunately,  he is the doctor, not I. I'll avoid giving him any medication at this  time. Perhaps, if he's kept quiet and warm, he may recover naturally.  It is agreeably warm here.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: I'm called Spock.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Prisoners?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Yes, we came through the time portal, but not as prisoners. We  were sent here by mistake.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: That is true. I am not from the world you know at all. My home  is a planet millions of light years away.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Listen to me. I am firmly convinced that I do exist. I am  substantial. You are not imagining this.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: McCoy. McCoy, wake up.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: No, we are still in the Ice Age, but safe for the moment.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Doctor, you're in no condition to get up. You lie down and rest.  I shall attempt to find the captain.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: He's our commanding officer and our friend.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: He did not come with us. He was sent through the time portal to  another period in history much later than this one. If I am to find  him, there is only one possible avenue. Zarabeth, will you show me  where the time portal is?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Yes, that is true. If I leave him, there's a chance he may never  regain the ship. He would then be marooned in this time period. But he  is no longer in danger of death, so my primary duty to him has been  discharged. If I remain here, no one of our party would be able to aid  Captain Kirk.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: It should be an equation. I should be able to resolve this  problem logically. Perhaps it has something to do with the atavachron.  If only I knew more about how it worked. Zarabeth, you said that you  were brought here as a prisoner. May I ask

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: I remember that name from the history tapes in the library. Zor  Kahn the Tyrant.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Zarabeth, I must return to Mister Atoz and the atavachron. We  will carry Doctor McCoy, and you must come with us. I will send you and  the doctor to the ship, and I shall search for Captain Kirk.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: You cannot go back?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Come, Doctor, back to bed.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: It is impossible to look for him, Doctor. We cannot go back.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Zarabeth explained it to me. When we came through the time  portal, it altered our physiological structure. If we attempt to return  to the library, we shall die.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Yes, Doctor, we are trapped. Just as Jim is trapped wherever he  is.   Captain's log, stardate 5943.9. The people of this  time believe in witches, and witchcraft is what I've been accused of.  Five witnesses heard McCoy's voice speak to me and thought it was an  evil spirit. From what I know of witchcraft trials, I don't have much  chance unless I can get to the prosecutor.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Really?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Doctor McCoy is making excellent progress.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: And known as the worst patient in the entire crew of the  Enterprise.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Five thousand years in the future.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Who knows. We can only hope that he is well, wherever he is.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: What was there to do?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: We've been through all that, Doctor. What's the point of  rehashing that subject? We can't get back. Wasn't that clear to you?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Then perhaps you were too ill to understand what can't get back  means.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Then I'll repeat it for you. Get this through your head. We  can't get back. That means we are trapped here in this planet's past  just as we are, and we'll stay here for the rest of our lives. Now do  you understand?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: The prospect appeared quite attractive to you a moment ago.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: I don't like that. I don't think I ever did, and now I'm sure.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Nothing that shouldn't have happened long ago.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: I'm sorry. I know of no way to return you to your own time.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Yes. I know what it is like.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: If it pleases you. This is animal flesh?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Naturally, because of the climate. What is the source of heat in  the shelter?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Excellent. Then it will be possible to build a greenhouse of  sorts. Meanwhile, this will have to do as the only source of  nourishment.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: But he evidently intended that you continue living.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: But insensitive, to send such a beautiful woman into exile. The  cold must've affected me more than I realised. Please pay no attention.  I'm not myself. I'm behaving disgracefully. I have eaten animal flesh  and I have enjoyed it. What is wrong with me? I tell you you're  beautiful. But you are beautiful. Is it so wrong to tell you so?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: You are beautiful. More beautiful than any dream of beauty I've  ever known.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: I've given you the facts, Doctor.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: You were told the truth. If Zarabeth is the source, what  difference does it make?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: She would not jeopardise other lives.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: What are you doing to her?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: This is impossible. Impossible. I am a Vulcan.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: My ancestors are barbarians. Warlike barbarians.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: I've lost myself. I do not know who I am. Can we go back?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: There's no portal here, Doctor. It's hopeless.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: You're too ill to remain out here any longer. Give it up.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: This must be it.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: You start ahead, Doctor. I do not wish to part from you.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: How much time do we have?

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: There's no further need to observe me, Doctor. As you can see,  I've returned to the present in every sense.

title: All  Our Yesterdays
dialogue: Yes, it happened. But that was five thousand years ago. And she  is dead now. Dead and buried. Long ago.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Captain. Tricorder picking up very faint life readings.  Approximately seven hundred metres from here. Help will have to be  immediate.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Captain, that will delay our work at Beta Aurigae. It means  reversing course.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: May I point out that Starbase Two is on the direct route to our  destination.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: If the diagnosis of Doctor Lester's illness is the critical  problem, then the Benecia Colony is definitely not the place for her.  Their medical facilities are the most primitive.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Starbase Two is fully equipped and staffed with the necessary  specialists to determine exactly what is wrong with the doctor. Is that  not crucial to your decision?

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: At maximum speed, Starbase Two would still meet the emergency.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Sir, I believe Starfleet will have to be notified that our  rendezvous with the starship Potemkin will not take place as scheduled.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Since the captain usually deals with Starfleet in these matters,  I assumed that my suggestions might be deemed interference.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Good. Knowledge of the captain's aberrant behaviour is spreading  through the ship. The crew is becoming increasingly tense.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: I'm afraid that is a forlorn hope, Doctor. The illness appears  to be primarily mental.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Perhaps the Surgeon General's office should be alerted.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Are you sure that the captain will comply with your order in his  present state of mind?

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Doctor, we are treading on very thin ground. Actions such as  these might be misinterpreted.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Whatever happened to the captain on that planet must've taken  place in the short space of time that he was alone with Doctor Lester.  Perhaps a conversation with her might shed some light.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: How is the doctor?

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Good. I have questions to ask her.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Why should he? They are my questions, therefore I am ordering  it, Lieutenant.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Has such an order ever included his senior officers?

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: By all means, Lieutenant.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Complete life-entity transfer with the aid  of a mechanical device?

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: To my knowledge, such total transfer has never been accomplished  with complete success anywhere in the galaxy.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: That is your claim. As yet, it is unsubstantiated by any  external evidence or objective tests.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: At this moment Doctor McCoy is examining the  captain for psychological changes. If any facts are uncovered, that  would be acceptable evidence. The only kind which is acceptable to  Starfleet Command and to the crew of the Enterprise.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: That is true. The captain did not. However, those events have  been recorded. They could have become known to you.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: I believe you. However, my belief is not acceptable evidence.  Evidence must be factual. Doctor McCoy may be of help. Come with me.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: He is not the captain.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Certainly, Lieutenant. We all must do our duty.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: It's quite all right, Ensign. Everything is  under control.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: A repetition of your physical violence is not called for, sir.  No physical resistance will be offered.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: I have stated my evidence. Telepathic communication with the  mind of Captain James T. Kirk.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: You've had great deal of evidence, except that of the chief  witness. The one who should be the real subject of this investigation  is kept locked away and in isolation. Why, Captain?

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: She is dangerous only to your authority, sir.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: The witness, sir. Bring on the witness. Let your officers put  the questions.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: I know them now.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: I am disappointed and deeply concerned that there is no  objective evidence to support my position. So far.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Sir, there is only one issue here. Is the story of life-entity  transfer believable? This crew has been to many places in the galaxy.  They've been witness to many strange events. They are trained to know  that what seems to be impossible often is possible, given the  scientific analysis of the phenomenon.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Not precisely, no.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: I expect only to reveal the truth.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: And what will become of Doctor Lester?

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: No, sir. I shall not withdraw a single charge that I have made.  You are not Captain Kirk. You have ruthlessly appropriated his body,  but the life entity within you is not that of Captain Kirk. You do not  belong in charge of the Enterprise and I shall do everything in my  power against you.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: I do. And I stand by it.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Yes, sir. An immediate vote before our chief witness can be left  to die on some obscure planet with the truth locked away inside of her.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: Perhaps you were.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: To accomplish that, each one of us must be ready to seize any  opportunity to break out of here and attack.

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: May I point out, Captain

title: Turnabout  Intruder
dialogue: I'm sure we all understand that, Captain.
